In late 1967 the PAVN lured American forces into the hinterlands at [Đắk
Tô](/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%AFk_T%C3%B4 "Đắk Tô") and at the [Marine Khe Sanh
combat base](/wiki/Battle_of_Khe_Sanh "Battle of Khe Sanh") in [Quảng Trị
Province](/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Tr%E1%BB%8B_Province "Quảng Trị Province") where
the United States had engaged, in a series of battles known as [The Hill
Fights](/wiki/The_Hill_Fights "The Hill Fights"). Part of this would form a
diversionary strategy that was meant to draw US forces towards the Central
Highlands.[234] Preparation for the _General Offensive, General Uprising_ ,
known as Tet Mau Than, or the [Tet Offensive](/wiki/Tet_Offensive "Tet
Offensive") was prepared, with the intention by [Văn Tiến
Dũng](/wiki/V%C4%83n_Ti%E1%BA%BFn_D%C5%A9ng "Văn Tiến Dũng") for forces to
launch "direct attacks on the American and puppet nerve centers—Saigon, Hue,
Danang, all the cities, towns and main bases.."[235] Hanoi sought to placate
critics of the ongoing stalemate and had sought a decisive victory.[236] They
had reasoned this could be achieved through sparking a general uprising within
the towns and cities[237] and mass-defections among ARVN units, who were on
holiday leave, during the period truce.[238] Over 100 cities were attacked by
over 85,000 enemy troops including assaults on key military installations,
headquarters, and government buildings and offices, including the [U.S.
Embassy in Saigon](/wiki/United_States_Embassy,_Saigon "United States Embassy,
Saigon").[239]

U.S. and South Vietnamese forces were initially shocked by the scale,
intensity and deliberative planning of the urban offensive, as infiltration of
personnel and weapons into the cities were done in intense covertness,[235]
and the offensive constituted an [intelligence
failure](/wiki/Failure_in_the_intelligence_cycle "Failure in the intelligence
cycle") on the scale of [Pearl Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on
Pearl Harbor").[225][240] Most cities were recaptured within weeks except the
former capital city of [Huế](/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF "Huế") in which NVA and Viet
Cong troops captured most of the city and citadel except the headquarters of
the [1st Division](/wiki/1st_Division_\(South_Vietnam\) "1st Division \(South
Vietnam\)") and held on in the fighting for 26 days.[241][242] During that
time, they had [executed approximately 2,800 unarmed
Huế](/wiki/Massacre_at_Hu%E1%BA%BF "Massacre at Huế") civilians and foreigners
they considered to be enemy's spies.[243] In the following [Battle of
Huế](/wiki/Battle_of_Hu%E1%BA%BF "Battle of Huế") American forces employed
massive firepower that left 80 percent of the city in ruins.[244] Further
north, at Quảng Trị City, the [ARVN Airborne
Division](/wiki/Republic_of_Vietnam_Airborne_Division "Republic of Vietnam
Airborne Division"), the [1st Division](/wiki/1st_Division_\(South_Vietnam\)
"1st Division \(South Vietnam\)") and a regiment of the US [1st Cavalry
Division](/wiki/1st_Cavalry_Division_\(United_States\) "1st Cavalry Division
\(United States\)") had managed to hold out and overcome an assault intended
to capture the city.[245][246] In Saigon, Viet Cong/NVA fighters had captured
areas in and around the city, attacking key installations and the
neighbourhood of Cholon before members of the [ARVN
Rangers](/wiki/Vietnamese_Rangers "Vietnamese Rangers") dislodged them after
three weeks.[247] During one battle, [Peter Arnett](/wiki/Peter_Arnett "Peter
Arnett"),[248] had reported an infantry commander saying of [Bến
Tre](/wiki/B%E1%BA%BFn_Tre "Bến Tre") (laid to rubble by U.S. attacks) that _"
it became necessary to destroy the village in order to save it."_[249]

During the first month of the offensive, 1,100 Americans and other allied
troops, 2,100 ARVN, 14,000 civilians, were killed[250] By the end of the first
offensive, after two months, nearly 5,000 ARVN were killed, over 4,000 U.S.
forces were killed, with total including wounded being 45,820 and an unknown
number of PAVN/NLF casualties,[250] with some U.S. authors claiming the NVA
and Viet Cong suffered 17,000 KIA and 32,000 total casualties including
wounded.[246][251] A month later a second offensive known as the [Phase II/May
Offensive](/wiki/May_Offensive "May Offensive") was launched, although less
widespread, it had still demonstrated the Viet Cong were still capable of
carrying out nationally orchestrated nationwide offensives.[252] Two months
following the May Offensive, a third offensive was launched, the [Phase
III/August Offensive](/wiki/Phase_III_Offensive "Phase III Offensive"). The
PAVN's own official records of their losses across all three offensives was
45,267 killed and 111,179 total casualties.[253][254] By then it had become
the bloodiest year of the war up to that point. The failure to spark a general
uprising, and the fact that no units within the ARVN defected meant both war
goals of Hanoi had fallen flat at enormous costs.[255]

Prior to Tet in November 1967, Westmoreland had spearheaded a public relations
drive for the Johnson administration to bolster flagging public support.[256]
In a speech before the [National Press Club](/wiki/National_Press_Club_\(USA\)
"National Press Club \(USA\)") he had said a point in the war had been reached
"where the end comes into view."[257] Thus, the public was shocked and
confused when Westmoreland's predictions were trumped by Tet.[256] For General
Westmoreland, public approval of his overall performance dropped from 48
percent to 36 percent—and endorsement for his war effort fell from 40 percent
to 26 percent."[258] The American public and media begun to turn against
Johnson as the three offensives had contradicted claims of progress made by
the Johnson administration and the military.[256]

At one point in 1968, Westmoreland considered the use of [nuclear
weapons](/wiki/Nuclear_weapons "Nuclear weapons") in Vietnam in a contingency
plan codenamed [Fracture Jaw](/wiki/Fracture_Jaw "Fracture Jaw"), which was
abandoned when it became known to the White House.[259]

Westmoreland's request for 200,000 additional troops had been leaked to the
media and the subsequent fallout combined with the intelligence failure caused
him to be removed from command on March 1968, succeeded by his deputy
[Creighton Abrams](/wiki/Creighton_Abrams "Creighton Abrams")[260]

meeting1967.jpg)

Soviet Premier [Alexei Kosygin](/wiki/Alexei_Kosygin "Alexei Kosygin") with

On 10 May 1968, [peace talks](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords "Paris Peace Accords")
began between the United States and North Vietnam in Paris. Negotiations
stagnated for five months, until Johnson gave orders to halt the bombing of
North Vietnam. At the same time, Hanoi realising it could not achieve a "total
victory" employed a strategy known as "talking while fighting, fighting while
talking", in which military offensives would occur concurrently with
negotiations.[261]

President Lyndon B. Johnson declined to run for re-election as his approval
rating slumped from 48 to 36 percent.[256] LBJ's escalation of the war in
Vietnam divided Americans into warring camps, cost 30,000 American lives by
that point and was regarded to have destroyed his presidency.[262] Refusal to
send more U.S. troops to Vietnam was also seen as Johnson's admission that the
war was lost.[263] As Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara noted, "the
dangerous illusion of victory by the United States was therefore dead."[264]

Vietnam was a major political issue during the [United States presidential
election in 1968](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1968 "United
States presidential election, 1968"). The election was won by Republican party
candidate [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon").

## Nixon Doctrine and Vietnamization, 1969–72

### Nuclear threats and diplomacy

U.S. President [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") began
troop withdrawals in 1969. His plan, called the [Nixon
Doctrine](/wiki/Nixon_Doctrine "Nixon Doctrine"), was to build up the ARVN, so
it could take over the defense of South Vietnam. The policy became known as
"[Vietnamization](/wiki/Vietnamization "Vietnamization")". Theater commander
[Creighton Abrams](/wiki/Creighton_Abrams "Creighton Abrams") shifted to
smaller operations, aimed at disrupting logistics, with better use of
firepower and more cooperation with the ARVN.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] On 27
October 1969, Nixon had ordered a squadron of 18
[B-52s](/wiki/Boeing_B-52_Stratofortress "Boeing B-52 Stratofortress") loaded
with nuclear weapons [to race to the border of Soviet
airspace](/wiki/Operation_Giant_Lance "Operation Giant Lance") to convince the
Soviet Union, in accord with the [madman theory](/wiki/Madman_theory "Madman
theory"), that he was capable of anything to end the Vietnam War ("Operation
Giant Lance").[265][266] Nixon had also sought [détente](/wiki/D%C3%A9tente
"Détente") with the Soviet Union and [rapprochement with China](/wiki/Sino-
American_relations#Rapprochement "Sino-American relations") which decreased
global tensions and led to nuclear arms reduction on the part of both
superpowers, however there was disappointed when both sides continued to
supply the North Vietnamese with aid.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Hanoi's war strategy

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Vietnampropaganda.png/170px-
Vietnampropaganda.png)](/wiki/File:Vietnampropaganda.png)

[](/wiki/File:Vietnampropaganda.png "Enlarge")

Propaganda leaflet urging the defection of Viet Cong and North Vietnamese to
the side of the Republic of Vietnam

In September 1969, Ho Chi Minh died at age seventy-nine.[267] The failure of
Tet in sparking a popular uprising caused a shift in Hanoi's war strategy and
the [Giáp](/wiki/V%C3%B5_Nguy%C3%AAn_Gi%C3%A1p "Võ Nguyên
Giáp")-[Chinh](/wiki/Tr%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_Chinh "Trường Chinh") "Northern-
First" faction had regained control over military affairs from the [Lê
Duẩn](/wiki/L%C3%AA_Du%E1%BA%A9n "Lê Duẩn")-[Hoàng Văn
Thái](/wiki/Ho%C3%A0ng_V%C4%83n_Th%C3%A1i "Hoàng Văn Thái") "Southern-First"
faction.[268] An unconventional victory was sidelined for a strategy built on
conventional victory through conquest.[269] Large-scale offensives were rolled
back in favour of [small-unit](/wiki/Low_intensity_conflict "Low intensity
conflict") and [sapper](/wiki/Commando "Commando") attacks as well as
targeting the [pacification](/wiki/Hearts_and_Minds_\(Vietnam_War\) "Hearts
and Minds \(Vietnam War\)") and Vietnamization strategy.[268] In the two-year
period following Tet, the PAVN had begun its transformation from a fine
[light-infantry,](/wiki/Light_infantry "Light infantry") limited mobility
force into a [high-mobile](/wiki/Maneuver_warfare "Maneuver warfare") and
mechanised [combined arms](/wiki/Combined_arms "Combined arms") force.[270]

### U.S. domestic controversies

The anti-war movement was gaining strength in the United States. Nixon
appealed to the "[silent majority](/wiki/Silent_majority "Silent majority")"
of Americans who he said supported the war without showing it in public. But
revelations of the [My Lai Massacre](/wiki/My_Lai_Massacre "My Lai Massacre"),
in which a U.S. Army [platoon](/wiki/My_Lai_Massacre#1st_Platoon "My Lai
Massacre") raped and killed civilians, and the 1969 "[Green Beret
Affair](/wiki/Green_Beret_Affair "Green Beret Affair")" where eight Special
Forces soldiers, including the 5th Special Forces Group Commander, were
arrested for the murder[271] of a suspected double agent[272] provoked
national and international outrage.

In 1971 the _[Pentagon Papers](/wiki/Pentagon_Papers "Pentagon Papers")_ were
leaked to _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York
Times")_. The top-secret history of U.S. involvement in Vietnam, commissioned
by the Department of Defense, detailed a long series of public deceptions on
the part of the U.S. government. The [Supreme
Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States") ruled that its publication was legal.[273]

### Collapsing U.S. morale

Following the Tet Offensive and the U.S. public beginning to publicly turn
against the war, U.S. forces begun a period of morale collapse,
disillusionment and disobedience.[274][275] At home, desertion rates
quadrupled from 1966 levels.[276] Among enlisted only 2.5% chose infantry
combat positions in 1969-1970.[276]
[ROTC](/wiki/Reserve_Officers%27_Training_Corps "Reserve Officers' Training
Corps") enrollment decreased from 191,749 in 1966 to 72,459 by 1971[277] and
reaching an all-time low of 33,220 in 1974,[278] depriving U.S. forces of
much-needed military leadership.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/30/Henri_Huet%2C_Cole.jpg/220px-
Henri_Huet%2C_Cole.jpg)](/wiki/File:Henri_Huet,_Cole.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Henri_Huet,_Cole.jpg "Enlarge")

Dying and wounded soldiers, photograph taken by [Henri Huet](/wiki/Henri_Huet
"Henri Huet"), who was later killed in a helicopter crash

Open refusal of engaging in patrols, carrying out orders and disobedience
begun to emerge during this period as well[279] with notable case of an entire
company refusing orders to engage or carry out operations.[280] Unit cohesion
begun to dissipate, and focused on minimising contact with Viet Cong and NVA
troops.[275] A practice known as "sand-bagging" started occurring, were units
ordered to go on patrol would go into the country-side, find a site out of
view from superiors and rest while radioing in false coordinates and unit
reports.[281] Drug usage increased rapidly among U.S. forces during this
period, as 30% of U.S. troops engaged in regular usage of marijuana[281] while
a House subcommittee found 10-15% of U.S. troops in Vietnam regularly used
high-grade heroin.[276][282] From 1969 on-ward search-and-destroy operations
started to become referred to as "search and evade" or "search and avoid"
operations, falsifying battle reports while avoiding guerrilla fighters.[283]
A total of 900 fragging and suspected [fragging](/wiki/Fragging "Fragging")
incidents were investigated, most occurring between 1969 and 1971.[282][281]
In 1969 field-performance of the U.S. Forces was characterised by lowered
morale, lack of motivation, and poor leadership.[284] One battle which is used
by historians to high-light the significant decline in U.S. morale was the
[Battle of FSB Mary Ann](/wiki/Battle_of_FSB_Mary_Ann "Battle of FSB Mary
Ann"), one of the final engagements in which a sapper attack had rampaged and
destroyed the base, relatively unchallenged.[285] [William
Westmoreland](/wiki/William_Westmoreland "William Westmoreland"), no-longer in
command but tasked with its investigation cited a clear dereliction of duty,
lax defensive postures and lack of officers being in charged as the
reason.[285]

On the collapse of U.S. morale, historian Shelby Stanton wrote:

> In the last years of the Army's retreat, its remaining forces were relegated
> to static security. The American Army's decline was readily apparent in this
> final stage. Racial incidents, drug abuse, combat disobedience, and crime
> reflected growing idleness, resentment, and frustration... the fatal
> handicaps of faulty campaign strategy, incomplete wartime preparation, and
> the tardy, superficial attempts at Vietnamization. An entire American army
> was sacrificed on the battlefield of Vietnam.[286]

### ARVN taking the lead and U.S. ground-force withdrawal

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/ARVN_and_US_Special_Forces.jpg/220px-
ARVN_and_US_Special_Forces.jpg)](/wiki/File:ARVN_and_US_Special_Forces.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ARVN_and_US_Special_Forces.jpg "Enlarge")

Group of Soldiers from ARVN with SFC Norman A. Doney, 5th S.F. Group Abn., 1st
S.F., Vietnam, Sept. 1968

Beginning in 1970, American troops were withdrawn from border areas where most
of the fighting took place, instead redeployed along the coast and interior,
and US casualties in 1970 were less than half of 1969 casualties after being
relegated to less active combat.[287] At the same time that US forces were
deployed, the [Army of the Republic of
Vietnam](/wiki/Army_of_the_Republic_of_Vietnam "Army of the Republic of
Vietnam") took over combat operations throughout the country, with casualties
doubled US casualties in 1969, and more than tripled US ones in 1970.[288] The
post-Tet environment saw a rise in membership in [Regional
Force](/wiki/South_Vietnamese_Regional_Force "South Vietnamese Regional
Force") and [Popular Force](/wiki/South_Vietnamese_Popular_Force "South
Vietnamese Popular Force") militias, now more capable of providing village
security which the Americans could not under Westmoreland.[289] In 1970 Nixon
announced the withdrawal of an additional 150,000 American troops, reducing
the number of Americans to 265,500.[287] By 1970 the Viet Cong forces were no-
longer southern-majority, and nearly 70% of units were northerners.[290]
Between 1969 and 1971 the Viet Cong and some PAVN units had reverted to [small
unit tactics](/wiki/Small_unit_tactics "Small unit tactics") typical of 1967
and prior instead of nationwide grand offensives.[269] In 1971 Australia and
New Zealand withdrew their soldiers and U.S. troop count was further reduced
to 196,700, with a deadline to remove another 45,000 troops by February 1972.
The United States also reduced support troops and in March 1971 the [5th
Special Forces Group](/wiki/5th_Special_Forces_Group_\(United_States\) "5th
Special Forces Group \(United States\)"), the first American unit deployed to
[South Vietnam](/wiki/South_Vietnam "South Vietnam"), withdrew to [Fort
Bragg](/wiki/Fort_Bragg "Fort Bragg"), [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina
"North Carolina").[291][A 4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Cambodian_Civil_War-
era_T-54_or_Type_59.jpg/220px-Cambodian_Civil_War-
era_T-54_or_Type_59.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cambodian_Civil_War-
era_T-54_or_Type_59.jpg)

### Cambodia

Main articles: [Operation Menu](/wiki/Operation_Menu "Operation Menu"),
[Operation Freedom Deal](/wiki/Operation_Freedom_Deal "Operation Freedom
Deal"), and [Cambodian Civil War](/wiki/Cambodian_Civil_War "Cambodian Civil
War")

Prince [Norodom Sihanouk](/wiki/Norodom_Sihanouk "Norodom Sihanouk") had
proclaimed Cambodia neutral since 1955,[294] but permitted the PAVN/NLF to use
Cambodia as a staging ground for the [Sihanouk Trail](/wiki/Sihanouk_Trail
"Sihanouk Trail"). Nixon had by then launched a massive bombing campaign,
called [Operation Menu](/wiki/Operation_Menu "Operation Menu"), against
communist sanctuaries along the Cambodia/Vietnam border. Only five high-
ranking Congressional officials were informed of Operation Menu.[295]

In 1970, Prince [Sihanouk was deposed](/wiki/Cambodian_coup_of_1970 "Cambodian
coup of 1970") by his pro-American prime minister [Lon Nol](/wiki/Lon_Nol "Lon
Nol"). North Vietnam invaded Cambodia in 1970 at the request of [Khmer
Rouge](/wiki/Khmer_Rouge "Khmer Rouge") deputy leader [Nuon
Chea](/wiki/Nuon_Chea "Nuon Chea").[296] A series of [military operations in
Cambodia](/wiki/Escape_of_the_Provisional_Revolutionary_Government "Escape of
the Provisional Revolutionary Government") by the South Vietnamese alongside
Lon Nol's FANK was the closest that the entire leadership of the Viet Cong
came to being captured. This was a goal that US/RVN Intelligence failed to
achieve for nearly a decade. Lon Nol had also started rounding up Vietnamese
civilians in Cambodia into internment camps and begun massacring them,
provoking harsh reactions from both the North Vietnamese and South Vietnamese
government.[297] A month after COSVN's escape, U.S. and ARVN forces launched
[a second invasion into Cambodia](/wiki/Cambodian_Campaign "Cambodian
Campaign") to attack NVA and Viet Cong bases. A counter-offensive later that
year as part of [Operation Chenla II](/wiki/Operation_Chenla_II "Operation
Chenla II") by the PAVN would recapture most of the border areas and decimate
most of Lon Nol's forces.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Vietconginterrogation.jpg/170px-
Vietconginterrogation.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietconginterrogation.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vietconginterrogation.jpg "Enlarge")

An alleged Viet Cong captured during an attack on an American outpost near the
Cambodian border is interrogated.

This invasion sparked [nationwide U.S.
protests](/wiki/Protests_against_the_Vietnam_War "Protests against the Vietnam
War") as Nixon had promised to deescalate the American involvement. [Four
students were killed by National Guardsmen](/wiki/Kent_State_shootings "Kent
State shootings") at [Kent State University](/wiki/Kent_State_University "Kent
State University") during a protest in [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio"), which
provoked further public outrage in the United States. The reaction to the
incident by the Nixon administration was seen as callous and indifferent,
providing additional impetus for the anti-war movement.[298] The U.S. Air
Force continued to heavily bomb Cambodia in support of the Cambodian
government as part of [Operation Freedom Deal](/wiki/Operation_Freedom_Deal
"Operation Freedom Deal").

### Laos

Main articles: [Operation Commando Hunt](/wiki/Operation_Commando_Hunt
"Operation Commando Hunt"), [Operation Lam Son
719](/wiki/Operation_Lam_Son_719 "Operation Lam Son 719"), and [Laotian Civil
War](/wiki/Laotian_Civil_War "Laotian Civil War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vientianne1973.jpg/220px-
Vientianne1973.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vientianne1973.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vientianne1973.jpg "Enlarge")

[Pathet Lao](/wiki/Pathet_Lao "Pathet Lao") soldiers in
[Vientiane](/wiki/Vientiane "Vientiane"), 1972

Building up on the success of ARVN units in Cambodia, and further testing the
Vietnamization program, the ARVN were tasked to launch [Operation Lam Son
719](/wiki/Operation_Lam_Son_719 "Operation Lam Son 719") in February 1971,
the first major operation aimed directly at occupying the [Ho Chi Minh
trail](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_trail "Ho Chi Minh trail") by attacking the major
crossroad of Tchperone. This offensive would also be the first time the PAVN
would field-test its [combined arms](/wiki/Combined_arms "Combined arms")
force.[269] The first few days were considered a success but the momentum had
slowed after fierce resistance. [Nguyễn Văn
Thiệu](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Thi%E1%BB%87u "Nguyễn Văn Thiệu") had
halted the general advance, leaving armoured divisions able to surround
them.[299] Thieu had ordered [air assault](/wiki/Air_assault "Air assault")
troops to capture Tchepone and withdraw, despite facing four-times larger
numbers. During the withdrawal the PAVN counterattack had forced a panicked
rout. Half of the ARVN troops involved were either captured or killed, half of
the ARVN/US support helicopters were downed by AA and the operation was
considered a fiasco, demonstrating operational deficiencies still present
within the ARVN.[300] [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") and
President Thieu had sought to use this event to show-case victory simply by
capturing Tchepone, and it was spun off as an "operational success".[299]

### Easter Offensive and Paris Peace Accords, 1972

Vietnamization was again tested by the [Easter
Offensive](/wiki/Easter_Offensive "Easter Offensive") of 1972, a massive
conventional NVA invasion of South Vietnam. The NVA and Viet Cong quickly
overran the northern provinces and in coordination with other forces attacked
from Cambodia, threatening to cut the country in half. U.S. troop withdrawals
continued. American airpower responded, beginning [Operation
Linebacker](/wiki/Operation_Linebacker "Operation Linebacker"), and the
offensive was halted.

The war was central to the [1972 U.S. presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1972 "United States
presidential election, 1972") as Nixon's opponent, [George
McGovern](/wiki/George_McGovern "George McGovern"), campaigned on immediate
withdrawal. Nixon's National Security Advisor, [Henry
Kissinger](/wiki/Henry_Kissinger "Henry Kissinger") had continued secret
negotiations with North Vietnam's [Lê Đức
Thọ](/wiki/L%C3%AA_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BB%8D "Lê Đức Thọ") and on October
1972 reached an agreement. President Thieu demanded changes to the peace
accord upon its discovery and when North Vietnam went public with the
agreement's details, the Nixon administration claimed they were attempting to
embarrass the president. The negotiations became deadlocked when Hanoi
demanded new changes. To show his support for South Vietnam and force Hanoi
back to the negotiating table, Nixon ordered [Operation Linebacker
II](/wiki/Operation_Linebacker_II "Operation Linebacker II"), a massive
bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong 18–29 December 1972. Nixon pressured Thieu to
accept the terms of the agreement, threatening to conclude a bilateral peace
deal and cut off American aid while promising an air-response in case of
invasion.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Viet_Cong_soldier_DD-
ST-99-04298.jpg/170px-Viet_Cong_soldier_DD-
ST-99-04298.jpg)](/wiki/File:Viet_Cong_soldier_DD-ST-99-04298.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Viet_Cong_soldier_DD-ST-99-04298.jpg "Enlarge")

Viet Cong soldier stands beneath a Viet Cong flag carrying his AK-47 rifle. He
was participating in the exchange of POWs by the [International Commission of
Control and
Supervision](/wiki/International_Commission_of_Control_and_Supervision
"International Commission of Control and Supervision").

On 15 January, all U.S. combat activities were suspended. [Lê Đức
Thọ](/wiki/L%C3%AA_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BB%8D "Lê Đức Thọ") and Henry
Kissinger, along with the [Provisional Revolutionary
Government](/wiki/Provisional_Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Republic_of_South_Vietnam
"Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam") \-
PRG (Viet Cong's government) Foreign Minister [Nguyễn Thị
Bình](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_B%C3%ACnh "Nguyễn Thị Bình") and a
reluctant President [Thiệu](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Thi%E1%BB%87u
"Nguyễn Văn Thiệu") signed the [Paris Peace Accords](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords
"Paris Peace Accords") on 27 January 1973.[301] This officially ended direct
U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War, created a ceasefire between North
Vietnam/PRG and South Vietnam, guaranteed the territorial integrity of Vietnam
under the [Geneva Conference](/wiki/Geneva_Conference_\(1954\) "Geneva
Conference \(1954\)") of 1954, called for elections or a political settlement
between the [Provisional Revolutionary
Government](/wiki/Provisional_Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Republic_of_South_Vietnam
"Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam") and
[South Vietnam](/wiki/South_Vietnam "South Vietnam") and allowed 200,000
communist troops to remain in the south, alongside a POW exchange. There was a
sixty-day period for the total withdrawal of U.S. forces. "This article",
noted Peter Church, "proved… to be the only one of the Paris Agreements which
was fully carried out."[302] All US forces personnel were completely withdrawn
by March 1973.[303]

## U.S. exit and final campaigns, 1973–75

In the lead-up to the ceasefire on 28 January, both sides attempted to
maximize the land and population under their control in a campaign known as
the [War of the flags](/wiki/War_of_the_flags "War of the flags"), fighting
continued after the ceasefire, this time without US participation and
continued throughout the year.[301] North Vietnam was allowed to continue
supplying troops in the South but only to the extent of replacing expended
material. Later that year the [Nobel Peace Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize
"Nobel Peace Prize") was awarded to Kissinger and Thọ, but the North
Vietnamese negotiator declined it saying that a true peace did not yet exist.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Hanoi-taxi-
march1973.jpg/220px-Hanoi-taxi-march1973.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hanoi-taxi-
march1973.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hanoi-taxi-march1973.jpg "Enlarge")

Recently released American POWs from North Vietnamese prison camps, 1973

On 15 March 1973, Nixon implied the US would intervene again militarily if the
North launched a full offensive and [Secretary of
Defense](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense "United States Secretary of
Defense") [James Schlesinger](/wiki/James_R._Schlesinger "James R.
Schlesinger") during his June 1973 confirmation hearings re-affirmed this.
Public and congressional reaction to Nixon's statement was unfavourable which
prompted the U.S. Senate to pass the [Case–Church
Amendment](/wiki/Case%E2%80%93Church_Amendment "Case–Church Amendment") to
prohibit an intervention.[304]

PAVN/VC leaders expected the ceasefire terms would favor their side but
Saigon, bolstered by a surge of U.S. aid received just before the ceasefire
went into effect, began to roll back the Viet Cong. The communists responded
with a new strategy hammered out in a series of meetings in Hanoi in March
1973, according to the memoirs of [Trần Văn
Trà](/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_V%C4%83n_Tr%C3%A0 "Trần Văn Trà").[305] With U.S.
bombings suspended, work on the Ho Chi Minh trail and other logistical
structures could proceed unimpeded. Logistics would be upgraded until the
North was in a position to launch a massive invasion of the South, projected
for 1975–76 dry season. Tra calculated that this date would be Hanoi's last
opportunity to strike before Saigon's army could be fully trained.[305] The
Viet Cong resumed offensive operations when the dry season begun in 1973, and
by January 1974, recaptured territory it lost during the previous dry season.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Vietcong_people.jpg/182px-
Vietcong_people.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietcong_people.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vietcong_people.jpg "Enlarge")

Civilians in a PAVN/NLF controlled zone. Civilians were required to show
appropriate flags, during the [War of the flags](/wiki/War_of_the_flags "War
of the flags").[306]

Within South Vietnam, there was increasing chaos as the departure of the US
military and the global recession that followed the [Arab oil
embargo](/wiki/1973_oil_crisis "1973 oil crisis") compromised an economy
partly dependent on U.S. financial support and troop presence. After two
clashes that left 55 South Vietnamese soldiers dead, President Thieu announced
on 4 January 1974, that the war had restarted and that the Paris Peace Accord
was no longer in effect. This was despite there being over 25,000 South
Vietnamese casualties during the ceasefire period.[307]

The success of the 1973–74 dry season offensive inspired Trà to return to
Hanoi in October 1974 and plead for a larger offensive the next dry season.
This time, Trà could travel on a drivable highway with regular fueling stops,
a vast change from the days when the Ho Chi Minh trail was a dangerous
mountain trek.[308] Giáp, the North Vietnamese defence minister, was reluctant
to approve of Trà's plan since a larger offensive might provoke U.S. reaction
and interfere with the big push planned for 1976. Trà appealed over Giáp's
head to first secretary [Lê Duẩn](/wiki/L%C3%AA_Du%E1%BA%A9n "Lê Duẩn"), who
approved of the operation. Trà's plan called for a limited offensive from
Cambodia into [Phước Long Province](/wiki/Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Long_Province
"Phước Long Province"). The strike was designed to solve local logistical
problems, gauge the reaction of South Vietnamese forces, and determine whether
U.S. would return.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/2a/Victory_Central_Highlands.JPG/170px-
Victory_Central_Highlands.JPG)](/wiki/File:Victory_Central_Highlands.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Victory_Central_Highlands.JPG "Enlarge")

Memorial commemorating the 1974 Buon Me Thuot campaign, depicting a
[Montagnard](/wiki/Degar "Degar") of the [Central
Highlands](/wiki/Central_Highlands,_Vietnam "Central Highlands, Vietnam"), a
PAVN soldier and a [T-54 tank](/wiki/T-54/T-55 "T-54/T-55")

At the start of 1975, the South Vietnamese had three times as much artillery
and twice the number of tanks and armoured cars as the opposition. They also
had 1,400 aircraft and a two-to-one numerical superiority in combat troops
over their Communist enemies.[309] However, the rising oil prices meant that
much of this could not be used, and the rushed nature of Vietnamization,
intended to cover the US retreat, saw a lack of spare parts, ground-crew and
maintenance personnel, rendering most of the equipment given inoperable.[310]
[Gerald Ford](/wiki/Gerald_Ford "Gerald Ford") took over as U.S. president on
9 August 1974 after President Nixon resigned due to the [Watergate
scandal](/wiki/Watergate_scandal "Watergate scandal") and Congress cut
financial aid to South Vietnam from $1 billion a year to $700 million.
Congress also voted in further restrictions on funding to be phased in through
1975 and to culminate in a total cutoff in 1976.

On 13 December 1974, North Vietnamese forces [attacked Route 14 in Phước Long
Province](/wiki/Battle_of_Phuoc_Long "Battle of Phuoc Long"). Phuoc Binh, the
provincial capital, fell on 6 January 1975. Ford desperately asked Congress
for funds to assist and re-supply the South before it was overrun.[311]
Congress refused.[311] The fall of Phuoc Binh and the lack of an American
response left the South Vietnamese elite demoralized.

The speed of this success led the Politburo to reassess its strategy. It was
decided that operations in the Central Highlands would be turned over to
General [Văn Tiến Dũng](/wiki/V%C4%83n_Ti%E1%BA%BFn_D%C5%A9ng "Văn Tiến Dũng")
and that Pleiku should be seized, if possible. Before he left for the South,
Dũng was addressed by Lê Duẩn: "Never have we had military and political
conditions so perfect or a strategic advantage as great as we have now."[312]

### Campaign 275

See also: [1975 Spring Offensive](/wiki/1975_Spring_Offensive "1975 Spring
Offensive"), [Battle of Ban Me Thuot](/wiki/Battle_of_Ban_Me_Thuot "Battle of
Ban Me Thuot"), and [Hue–Da Nang Campaign](/wiki/Hue%E2%80%93Da_Nang_Campaign
"Hue–Da Nang Campaign")

On 10 March 1975, General Dung launched Campaign 275, a limited offensive into
the Central Highlands, supported by tanks and heavy artillery. The target was
[Buôn Ma Thuột](/wiki/Battle_of_Buon_Me_Thuot "Battle of Buon Me Thuot"), in
[Đắk Lắk Province](/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%AFk_L%E1%BA%AFk_Province "Đắk Lắk
Province"). If the town could be taken, the provincial capital of
[Pleiku](/wiki/Pleiku "Pleiku") and the road to the coast would be exposed for
a planned campaign in 1976. The ARVN proved incapable of resisting the
onslaught, and its forces collapsed on 11 March. Once again, Hanoi was
surprised by the speed of their success. Dung now urged the Politburo to allow
him to seize Pleiku immediately and then turn his attention to [Kon
Tum](/wiki/Kon_Tum "Kon Tum"). He argued that with two months of good weather
remaining until the onset of the monsoon, it would be irresponsible to not
take advantage of the situation.[56]

President [Nguyễn Văn Thiệu](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Thi%E1%BB%87u
"Nguyễn Văn Thiệu"), a former general, was fearful that his forces would be
cut off in the north by the attacking communists; Thieu ordered a retreat,
which soon turned into a bloody rout. While the bulk of ARVN forces attempted
to flee, isolated units fought desperately. ARVN General Phu abandoned Pleiku
and Kon Tum and retreated toward the coast, in what became known as the
"column of tears".[56]

On 20 March, Thieu reversed himself and ordered Huế, Vietnam's third-largest
city, be held at all costs, and then changed his policy several times. As the
North Vietnamese launched their attack, panic set in, and ARVN resistance
withered. On 22 March, the NVA opened the siege of Huế. Civilians flooded the
airport and the docks hoping for any mode of escape.[56] As resistance in Huế
collapsed, North Vietnamese rockets rained down on [Da Nang](/wiki/Hue-
Da_Nang_Campaign "Hue-Da Nang Campaign") and its airport. By 28 March 35,000
VPA troops were poised to attack the suburbs. By 30 March 100,000 leaderless
ARVN troops surrendered as the NVA marched victoriously through Da Nang. With
the fall of the city, the defense of the Central Highlands and Northern
provinces came to an end.[56]

### Final North Vietnamese offensive

Further information on the final North Vietnamese offensive: [Ho Chi Minh
Campaign](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_Campaign "Ho Chi Minh Campaign")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Xuanloc_18th.jpg/170px-
Xuanloc_18th.jpg)](/wiki/File:Xuanloc_18th.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Xuanloc_18th.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lê Minh Đảo](/wiki/L%C3%AA_Minh_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3o "Lê Minh Đảo") and remnants
of the [18th Division](/wiki/18th_Division_\(South_Vietnam\) "18th Division
\(South Vietnam\)") and surviving units made a last stand at the [Battle of
Xuân Lộc](/wiki/Battle_of_Xu%C3%A2n_L%E1%BB%99c "Battle of Xuân Lộc").

With the northern half of the country under their control, the Politburo
ordered General Dung to launch the final offensive against Saigon. The
operational plan for the [Ho Chi Minh Campaign](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_Campaign "Ho
Chi Minh Campaign") called for the capture of Saigon before 1 May. Hanoi
wished to avoid the coming monsoon and prevent any redeployment of ARVN forces
defending the capital. Northern forces, their morale boosted by their recent
victories, rolled on, taking Nha Trang, Cam Ranh, and Da Lat.

On 7 April, three North Vietnamese divisions attacked [Xuân
Lộc](/wiki/Battle_of_Xu%C3%A2n_L%E1%BB%99c "Battle of Xuân Lộc"), 40 miles (64
km) east of Saigon. For two bloody weeks, severe fighting raged as the ARVN
defenders made a [last stand](/wiki/Last_stand "Last stand") to try to block
the North Vietnamese advance. By 21 April, however, the exhausted garrison
were ordered to withdraw towards Saigon. An embittered and tearful president
Thieu resigned on the same day, declaring that the United States betrayed
South Vietnam. In a scathing attack, he suggested U.S. Secretary of State
Henry Kissinger had tricked him into signing the Paris peace agreement two
years earlier, promising military aid that failed to materialize. Having
transferred power to [Trần Văn
Hương](/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_V%C4%83n_H%C6%B0%C6%A1ng "Trần Văn Hương"), he left
for [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") on 25 April.

By the end of April, the ARVN collapsed on all fronts except in the [Mekong
Delta](/wiki/Mekong_Delta "Mekong Delta"). Thousands of refugees streamed
southward, ahead of the main communist onslaught. On 27 April 100,000 North
Vietnamese troops encircled Saigon. The city was defended by about 30,000 ARVN
troops. To hasten a collapse and foment panic, the NVA shelled the airport and
forced its closure. With the air exit closed, large numbers of civilians found
that they had no way out.

### Fall of Saigon

Main article: [Fall of Saigon](/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon "Fall of Saigon")

Further information: [Operation Frequent Wind](/wiki/Operation_Frequent_Wind
"Operation Frequent Wind")

Chaos, unrest, and panic broke out as hysterical South Vietnamese officials
and civilians scrambled to leave Saigon. [Martial law](/wiki/Martial_law
"Martial law") was declared. American helicopters began evacuating South
Vietnamese, U.S., and foreign nationals from various parts of the city and
from the U.S. embassy compound. [Operation Frequent
Wind](/wiki/Operation_Frequent_Wind "Operation Frequent Wind") had been
delayed until the last possible moment, because of U.S. Ambassador [Graham
Martin](/wiki/Graham_Martin "Graham Martin")'s belief that Saigon could be
held and that a political settlement could be reached.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Parade_Unification.jpg/220px-
Parade_Unification.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parade_Unification.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Parade_Unification.jpg "Enlarge")

Reunification parade following the Fall of Saigon, with the city being renamed
to Ho Chi Minh City

Schlesinger announced early in the morning of 29 April 1975 the evacuation
from [Saigon](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City "Ho Chi Minh City") by helicopter of the
last U.S. diplomatic, military, and civilian personnel. Frequent Wind was
arguably the largest helicopter evacuation in history. It began on 29 April,
in an atmosphere of desperation, as hysterical crowds of Vietnamese vied for
limited space. Martin pleaded with Washington to dispatch $700 million in
emergency aid to bolster the regime and help it mobilize fresh military
reserves. But American public opinion had soured on this conflict.

President [Gerald Ford](/wiki/Gerald_Ford "Gerald Ford") had given a televised
speech on 23 April, declaring an end to the Vietnam War and all U.S. aid.
Frequent Wind continued around the clock, as North Vietnamese tanks breached
defenses on the outskirts of Saigon. In the early morning hours of 30 April,
the last U.S. Marines evacuated the embassy by helicopter, as civilians
swamped the perimeter and poured into the grounds. Many of them had been
employed by the Americans and were left to their fate.

On 30 April 1975, NVA troops entered the city of Saigon and quickly overcame
all resistance, capturing key buildings and installations. A tank from the
324th Division crashed through the gates of the [Independence
Palace](/wiki/Independence_Palace "Independence Palace") at 11:30 am local
time and the Viet Cong flag was raised above it. President [Dương Văn
Minh](/wiki/D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_V%C4%83n_Minh "Dương Văn Minh"), who had succeeded
Huong two days earlier, surrendered to Colonel [Bùi
Tín](/wiki/B%C3%B9i_T%C3%ADn "Bùi Tín").[313]

## Opposition to U.S. involvement in the war, 1964–73

Main articles: [Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam
War](/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War
"Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War") and [Protests of
1968](/wiki/Protests_of_1968 "Protests of 1968")

See also: [Russell Tribunal](/wiki/Russell_Tribunal "Russell Tribunal") and
[Fulbright Hearings](/wiki/Fulbright_Hearings "Fulbright Hearings")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Vietnam_War_protesters._1967._Wichita%2C_Kans_-
_NARA_-_283627.jpg/170px-Vietnam_War_protesters._1967._Wichita%2C_Kans_-
_NARA_-_283627.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietnam_War_protesters._1967._Wichita,_Kans_-
_NARA_-_283627.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vietnam_War_protesters._1967._Wichita,_Kans_-_NARA_-_283627.jpg
"Enlarge")

Anti-war protests

During the course of the Vietnam War a large segment of the American
population came to be opposed to U.S. involvement in Southeast Asia. Public
opinion steadily turned against the war following 1967 and by 1970 only a
third of Americans believed that the U.S. had not made a mistake by sending
troops to fight in Vietnam.[314] Nearly a third of the American population
were strongly against the war, a position which lasted through subsequent
decades.[315]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Vietnamdem.jpg/220px-
Vietnamdem.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietnamdem.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vietnamdem.jpg "Enlarge")

Anti-Vietnam War demonstration, 1967

Early opposition to U.S. involvement in Vietnam drew its inspiration from the
[Geneva Conference of 1954](/wiki/Geneva_Conference_\(1954\) "Geneva
Conference \(1954\)"). American support of Diệm in refusing elections was seen
as thwarting the democracy America claimed to support. John F. Kennedy, while
Senator, opposed involvement in Vietnam.[210] Nonetheless, it is possible to
specify certain groups who led the anti-war movement at its peak in the late
1960s and the reasons why. Many young people protested because they were the
ones being [drafted](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in
the United States") while others were against the war because the anti-war
movement grew increasingly popular among the
[counterculture](/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s "Counterculture of the
1960s"). Some advocates within the peace movement advocated a
[unilateral](/wiki/Unilateral "Unilateral") withdrawal of U.S. forces from
Vietnam. Opposition to the Vietnam War tended to unite groups opposed to U.S.
anti-communism and [imperialism](/wiki/American_imperialism "American
imperialism")[316] and, for those involved with the [New Left](/wiki/New_Left
"New Left") such as the [Catholic Worker
Movement](/wiki/Catholic_Worker_Movement "Catholic Worker Movement"). Others,
such as [Stephen Spiro](/wiki/Stephen_Spiro "Stephen Spiro") opposed the war
based on the theory of [Just War](/wiki/Just_War "Just War"). Some wanted to
show solidarity with the people of Vietnam, such as [Norman
Morrison](/wiki/Norman_Morrison "Norman Morrison") emulating the [self-
immolation](/wiki/Self-immolation "Self-immolation") of [Thích Quảng
Đức](/wiki/Th%C3%ADch_Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c "Thích Quảng Đức").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Vietnam_War_protests_in_Vienna%2C_Austria_%28Greyscale%29.jpg/220px-
Vietnam_War_protests_in_Vienna%2C_Austria_%28Greyscale%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietnam_War_protests_in_Vienna,_Austria_\(Greyscale\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vietnam_War_protests_in_Vienna,_Austria_\(Greyscale\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Vietnam War protesters in [Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") in 1968

High-profile opposition to the Vietnam War increasingly turned to mass
protests in an effort to shift U.S. public opinion. Riots broke out at the
[1968 Democratic National
Convention](/wiki/1968_Democratic_National_Convention "1968 Democratic
National Convention") during protests against the war.[317] After news reports
of American [military abuses](/wiki/Military_abuses "Military abuses") such as
the 1968 [My Lai Massacre](/wiki/My_Lai_Massacre "My Lai Massacre"), brought
new attention and support to the anti-war movement, some veterans joined
[Vietnam Veterans Against the War](/wiki/Vietnam_Veterans_Against_the_War
"Vietnam Veterans Against the War"). On 15 October 1969, the [Vietnam
Moratorium](/wiki/Moratorium_to_End_the_War_in_Vietnam "Moratorium to End the
War in Vietnam") attracted millions of Americans.[318] The [fatal
shooting](/wiki/Kent_State_shootings "Kent State shootings") of four students
at [Kent State University](/wiki/Kent_State_University "Kent State
University") in 1970 led to nationwide university protests.[319] Anti-war
protests declined with the final withdrawal of troops after the [Paris Peace
Accords](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords "Paris Peace Accords") in 1973.

In 1950, China extended [diplomatic recognition](/wiki/Diplomatic_recognition
"Diplomatic recognition") to the [Viet Minh](/wiki/Viet_Minh "Viet Minh")'s
[Democratic Republic of Vietnam](/wiki/North_Vietnam "North Vietnam") and sent

first draft of the 1954 [Geneva Accords](/wiki/Geneva_Conference_\(1954\)
"Geneva Conference \(1954\)") was negotiated by French prime minister [Pierre
Mendès France](/wiki/Pierre_Mend%C3%A8s_France "Pierre Mendès France") and
Chinese Premier [Zhou Enlai](/wiki/Zhou_Enlai "Zhou Enlai") who, seeing U.S.
intervention coming, urged the Viet Minh to accept a partition at the [17th
parallel](/wiki/17th_parallel_north "17th parallel north").[321]

China's support for North Vietnam when the U.S. started to intervene included
both financial aid and the deployment of hundreds of thousands of military
personnel in support roles. In the summer of 1962, [Mao
Zedong](/wiki/Mao_Zedong "Mao Zedong") agreed to supply Hanoi with 90,000
rifles and guns free of charge. Starting in 1965, China sent [anti-
aircraft](/wiki/Anti-aircraft_warfare "Anti-aircraft warfare") units and
engineering [battalions](/wiki/Battalion "Battalion") to North Vietnam to
repair the damage caused by American bombing, man anti-aircraft batteries,
rebuild roads and railroads, transport supplies, and perform other engineering
works. This freed North Vietnamese army units for combat in the South. China
sent 320,000 troops and annual arms shipments worth $180 million.[322] The
Chinese military claims to have caused 38% of American air losses in the
war.[31] China claimed that its military and economic aid to North Vietnam and
the Viet Cong totaled $20 billion (approx. $143 billion adjusted for inflation
in 2015) during the Vietnam War.[31] Included in that aid were donations of 5
million tons of food to North Vietnam (equivalent to NV food production in a
single year), accounting for 10–15% of the North Vietnamese food supply by the
1970s.[31]

Soviet ships in the South China Sea gave vital early warnings to [Viet
Cong](/wiki/Viet_Cong "Viet Cong") forces in South Vietnam. The Soviet
intelligence ships would pick up American
[B-52](/wiki/Boeing_B-52_Stratofortress "Boeing B-52 Stratofortress") bombers
flying from [Okinawa](/wiki/Okinawa_Prefecture "Okinawa Prefecture") and
[Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"). Their airspeed and direction would be noted and
then relayed to [COSVN](/wiki/COSVN "COSVN"), North Vietnam's southern
headquarters. Using airspeed and direction, COSVN analysts would calculate the
bombing target and tell any assets to move "perpendicularly to the attack
trajectory." These advance warnings gave them time to move out of the way of
the bombers, and, while the bombing runs caused extensive damage, because of
the early warnings from 1968 to 1970 they did not kill a single military or
civilian leader in the headquarters complexes.[326]

The Soviet Union supplied North Vietnam with medical supplies, arms, tanks,
planes, helicopters, artillery, anti-aircraft missiles and other military
equipment. Soviet crews fired Soviet-made [surface-to-air
missiles](/wiki/Surface-to-air_missile "Surface-to-air missile") at U.S. [F-4
Phantoms](/wiki/F-4_Phantom_II "F-4 Phantom II"), which were shot down over
Thanh Hóa in 1965. Over a dozen Soviet citizens lost their lives in this
conflict. Following the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, Russian
officials acknowledged that the Soviet Union had stationed up to 3,000 troops
in Vietnam during the war.[327]

Some Russian sources give more specific numbers: Between 1953 and 1991, the
hardware donated by the Soviet Union included 2,000 tanks, 1,700
[APCs](/wiki/Armoured_personnel_carrier "Armoured personnel carrier"), 7,000
artillery guns, over 5,000 anti-aircraft guns, 158 surface-to-air missile
launchers, 120 helicopters. During the war, the Soviets sent North Vietnam
annual arms shipments worth $450 million.[328][329] From July 1965 to the end
of 1974, fighting in Vietnam was observed by some 6,500 officers and generals,
as well as more than 4,500 soldiers and sergeants of the Soviet Armed Forces.
In addition, Soviet military schools and academies began training Vietnamese
soldiers—in all more than 10,000 military personnel.[330]

The [KGB](/wiki/KGB "KGB") had also helped developed the [signals
intelligence](/wiki/Signals_intelligence "Signals intelligence") capabilities
of the North Vietnamese, through an operation known as Vostok (also known as
Phương Đông, meaning "Orient" and named after the [Vostok 1](/wiki/Vostok_1
"Vostok 1")).[331] The Vostok program was a
[counterintelligence](/wiki/Counterintelligence "Counterintelligence") and
[espionage](/wiki/Espionage "Espionage") program. These programs were pivotal
in detecting and defeating CIA and South Vietnamese commando teams sent into
North Vietnam, as they were detected and captured.[331] The Soviets helped the
[Ministry of Public Security](/wiki/Ministry_of_Public_Security_\(Vietnam\)
"Ministry of Public Security \(Vietnam\)") recruite foreigners within high-
level diplomatic circles among the Western-allies of the US, under a
clandestine program known as "B12,MM" which produced thousands of high-level
documents for nearly a decade, including targets of B-52 strikes.[331] In
1975, the [SIGINT](/wiki/Signals_intelligence "Signals intelligence") services
had broken information from Western US-allies in Saigon, determining that the
US would not intervene to save South Vietnam from collapse.[331]

#### Czechoslovakia

The [Czechoslovak Socialist Republic](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic
"Czechoslovak Socialist Republic") was a member of the [Warsaw
Pact](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact "Warsaw Pact") and sent significant aid to [North
Vietnam](/wiki/North_Vietnam "North Vietnam"), both prior to and after the
[Prague Spring](/wiki/Prague_Spring "Prague Spring").[333] The Czechoslovakian
government created committees which sought to not only promote and establish
peace, but also to promote victory for Viet Cong and Viet Minh forces.[333] In
the wake of the Prague Spring uprising, Czechoslovakia saw increasing
parallels between its own conflict with the Soviet Union and North Vietnam's
increasing conflict with the United States.[333] Czech-made equipment and
military aid would increase significantly following the Prague Spring.[334]
Czechoslovakian weapons created by [Česká zbrojovka Uherský
Brod](/wiki/%C4%8Cesk%C3%A1_zbrojovka_Uhersk%C3%BD_Brod "Česká zbrojovka
Uherský Brod") with the [Vz. 58](/wiki/Vz._58 "Vz. 58") being alleged to be
highly valued among [People's Army of
Vietnam](/wiki/People%27s_Army_of_Vietnam "People's Army of Vietnam")
forces,[_[why?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_]
and Czechoslovakia continued to send tens of thousands of Czech-made rifles
alongside mortar and artillery throughout the war.[334] In general, the
[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic](/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic
"Czechoslovak Socialist Republic") were quite aligned with European leftist
movements,[333] and there were simultaneous protests ongoing demonstrating
against both the Soviet-intervention in Prague as well as the US intervention
in Vietnam.[335]

Cooperation between North Vietnam and Czechoslovakia on the development of its
air capabilities begun as early as 1956.[336] Czechoslovak instructors and
trainers had instructed the [North Vietnam Air
Force](/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Air_Force "Vietnam People's Air Force") in
China and had helped them develop a modernised airforce, with the Czech-built
[Aero Ae-45](/wiki/Aero_Ae-45 "Aero Ae-45") and [Aero L-29
Delfín](/wiki/Aero_L-29_Delf%C3%ADn "Aero L-29 Delfín") alongside [Zlín Z
26](/wiki/Zl%C3%ADn_Z_26 "Zlín Z 26") aircraft utilised significantly for
training, and regarded as preferential to Soviet-built [Yakovlev
Yak-3](/wiki/Yakovlev_Yak-3 "Yakovlev Yak-3") as training aircraft.[336]

#### North Korea

As a result of a decision of the [Korean Workers'
Party](/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Korea "Workers' Party of Korea") in October
1966, in early 1967 [North Korea](/wiki/North_Korea "North Korea") sent a
fighter squadron to North Vietnam to back up the North Vietnamese 921st and
923rd fighter squadrons defending Hanoi. They stayed through 1968, and 200
pilots were reported to have served.[337] In addition, at least two anti-
aircraft artillery regiments were sent as well.[338]

The contributions to North Vietnam by the [Republic of Cuba](/wiki/Cuba
"Cuba") under [Fidel Castro](/wiki/Fidel_Castro "Fidel Castro") have been
recognized several times by representatives of the Democratic Republic of
Vietnam.[339] Castro mentioned in his discourses the Batallón Girón (Giron
Battalion) as comprising the Cuban contingent that served as [military
advisors](/wiki/Military_advisor "Military advisor") during the war.[340] In
this battalion, alongside the Cubans, fought [Nguyễn Thị
Định](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh "Nguyễn Thị Định"),
founding member of the Viet Cong, who later became the first female Major
General in the North Vietnamese Army.[341]

There are numerous allegations by former U.S. [prisoners of
war](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war") that Cuban military personnel
were present at North Vietnamese prison facilities during the war and that
they participated in torture activities. Witnesses to this include [Senator
John McCain](/wiki/John_McCain "John McCain"), 2008 [U.S. Presidential
candidate](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election "United States
presidential election") and former Vietnam prisoner of war, according to his
1999 book _[Faith of My Fathers](/wiki/Faith_of_My_Fathers "Faith of My
Fathers")_.[342]

#### East Germany

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Stamps_of_Germany_%28DDR%29_1968%2C_MiNr_1371.jpg/130px-
Stamps_of_Germany_%28DDR%29_1968%2C_MiNr_1371.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stamps_of_Germany_\(DDR\)_1968,_MiNr_1371.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stamps_of_Germany_\(DDR\)_1968,_MiNr_1371.jpg "Enlarge")

[East German](/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany") solidarity stamp depicting a
Vietnamese mother and child

[German Democratic Republic](/wiki/East_Germany "East Germany"). The [Ministry
of Public Security](/wiki/Ministry_of_Public_Security_\(Vietnam\) "Ministry of
Public Security \(Vietnam\)") of Vietnam (_Bộ Công An_) states there was
special interest towards the [Stasi](/wiki/Stasi "Stasi") in establishing an
intelligence and security apparatus, particularly since the Stasi was well-
regarded, considered "industrial, modern, and (with a) scientific working-
style".[343] In official Vietnamese language histories on the Vietnamese
Ministry of Public Security, the assistance provided by the Soviet and East
German intelligence services to Vietnam is usually rated as the most important
within the socialist bloc.[343] East Germany had also provided a substantive
aid in helping North Vietnam duplicate "Green Dragon" identity cards, which
were difficult to duplicate identity cards created by Saigon in order to
identify North Vietnamese combatants.[343]

East German authorities had also begun providing material and technical aid to
help develop and modernise the North Vietnamese economy and military.[343]
Alongside providing military and economic aid, East Germany had also
vigorously denounced the US war effort, and had reaped significant
international and diplomatic standing as a result of its anti-war
campaigns.[344]

#### Poland

The [Polish People's Republic](/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic "Polish
People's Republic") had played a substantive role in brokering and serving as
an intermediary for peace-talks between Hanoi and Saigon, as part of a
delegation under the [International Control
Commission](/wiki/International_Control_Commission "International Control
Commission") alongside Western European nations. Recent evidence has emerged
that Poland played an early role in attempting to broker talks between [Ngô
Đình Nhu](/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Nhu "Ngô Đình Nhu") and the Diem
regime and Hanoi in 1963 in an effort to prevent the expansion of the war,
given that Polish representatives were the only communist nation present in
Saigon and had acted as a broker and representative on behalf of Hanoi.[345]

### Pro-Saigon

See also: [Southeast Asia Treaty
Organization](/wiki/Southeast_Asia_Treaty_Organization "Southeast Asia Treaty
Organization")

As South Vietnam was formally part of a military alliance with the US,
Australia and New Zealand, France, the [UK](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United
Kingdom"), [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan"), [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand
"Thailand") and the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), the
alliance was invoked during the war. The UK, France and Pakistan declined to
participate, and South Korea and Taiwan were non-treaty participants.

#### South Korea

Main article: [South Korea in the Vietnam
War](/wiki/South_Korea_in_the_Vietnam_War "South Korea in the Vietnam War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Photo_taken_by_Phillip_Kemp_from_cockpit_after_sling-
loading_water_drums_to_outpost..jpg/220px-
Photo_taken_by_Phillip_Kemp_from_cockpit_after_sling-

On the [anti-communist](/wiki/Anti-communism "Anti-communism") side, [South
Korea](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea") (a.k.a. the Republic of Korea, ROK)
had the second-largest contingent of foreign troops in South Vietnam after the
United States. In November 1961, President [Park Chung-hee](/wiki/Park_Chung-
hee "Park Chung-hee") proposed South Korean participation in the war to John
F. Kennedy, but Kennedy disagreed as they were not [SEATO](/wiki/SEATO
"SEATO") treaty members.[346] On 1 May 1964 [Lyndon
Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_Johnson "Lyndon Johnson") agreed to permit South Korean
participation under the [Many-Flags Program](/w/index.php?title=Many-
Flags_Program&action=edit&redlink=1 "Many-Flags Program \(page does not
exist\)") in return for monetary compensation.[346] The first South Korean
troops began arriving in 1964 and large combat formations began arriving a
year later. The [ROK Marine Corps](/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Marine_Corps
"Republic of Korea Marine Corps") dispatched their [2nd Marine
Brigade](/wiki/2nd_Marine_Brigade_\(Republic_of_Korea\) "2nd Marine Brigade
\(Republic of Korea\)") while the ROK Army sent the [Capital
Division](/wiki/Capital_Division "Capital Division") and later the [9th
Infantry Division](/wiki/9th_Infantry_Division_\(Republic_of_Korea\) "9th
Infantry Division \(Republic of Korea\)"). In August 1966 after the arrival of
the 9th Division the Koreans established a corps command, the Republic of
Korea Forces Vietnam Field Command, near [I Field Force,
Vietnam](/wiki/I_Field_Force,_Vietnam "I Field Force, Vietnam") at [Nha
Trang](/wiki/Nha_Trang "Nha Trang").[347]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Phong_Nhi_massacre_4.jpg/220px-
Phong_Nhi_massacre_4.jpg)](/wiki/File:Phong_Nhi_massacre_4.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Phong_Nhi_massacre_4.jpg "Enlarge")

South Vietnamese civilians of [Phong
Nhi](/wiki/Phong_Nhi_and_Phong_Nhat_massacre "Phong Nhi and Phong Nhat
massacre") village massacred by South Korean [Blue Dragon
Brigade](/wiki/2nd_Marine_Division_\(Republic_of_Korea\) "2nd Marine Division
\(Republic of Korea\)") in 1968

Official records are vindictive of the role of ROK Forces in the war, as State
Department reports publicly questioned their usefulness in the conflict, as
they have "appeared to have been reluctant to undertake offensive operations,
and are only useful in guarding a small sector of the populated area".[348]
State department reports furthermore state that ROK forces engaged in
systemic, well-organised corruption in diverting US-equipment, and that actual
security has often been provided by [ARVN Territorial
Forces](/wiki/South_Vietnamese_Regional_Force "South Vietnamese Regional
Force") whom lacked organic firepower and heavy artillery but served as a
buffer between Korean units and the North Vietnamese Army.[349] In addition, a
RAND author conducting studies in South Vietnam in 1970 alleges that ROK
forces had a "deliberate, systematic policy of committing atrocities"
prompting civilians to leave ROK-controlled sectors.[350] The conduct of ROK
forces often emboldened and strengthened the Viet Cong, adding ranks from an
otherwise neutral population and undermining efforts to defeat the insurgency
overall.[351]

Approximately 320,000 South Korean soldiers were sent to Vietnam,[352] each
serving a one-year tour of duty. Maximum troop levels peaked at 50,000 in
1968, however all were withdrawn by 1973.[353] About 5,099 South Koreans were
killed and 10,962 wounded during the war. South Korea claimed to have killed
41,000 Viet Cong.[352] An unknown percentage of 'enemy combatants' may have
been unarmed civilians, as ROK Forces were estimated to have deliberately
killed at least 9,000 civilians.[354][355] The United States paid South Korean
soldiers 236 million dollars for their efforts in Vietnam,[352] and South
Korean [GNP](/wiki/GNP "GNP") increased five-fold during the war.[352]

Thai Army formations, including the [Royal Thai Volunteer
Regiment](/wiki/Royal_Thai_Volunteer_Regiment "Royal Thai Volunteer Regiment")
(Queen's Cobras) and later the [Royal Thai Army Expeditionary
Division](/wiki/Royal_Thai_Army_Expeditionary_Division "Royal Thai Army

outnumbered by the irregular "volunteers" of the CIA-sponsored Police Aerial
Reconnaissance Units or PARU, who carried out reconnaissance activities on the
western side of the Ho Chi Minh trail.[56]

#### Australia and New Zealand

Main articles: [Military history of Australia during the Vietnam
War](/wiki/Military_history_of_Australia_during_the_Vietnam_War "Military
history of Australia during the Vietnam War") and [New Zealand in the Vietnam
War](/wiki/New_Zealand_in_the_Vietnam_War "New Zealand in the Vietnam War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/RAR_Vietnam.jpg/170px-
RAR_Vietnam.jpg)](/wiki/File:RAR_Vietnam.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RAR_Vietnam.jpg "Enlarge")

An Australian soldier in Vietnam

Australia and New Zealand, close allies of the United States and members of
the [Southeast Asia Treaty
Organization](/wiki/Southeast_Asia_Treaty_Organization "Southeast Asia Treaty
Organization") (SEATO) and the [ANZUS](/wiki/ANZUS "ANZUS") military co-
operation treaty, sent ground troops to Vietnam. Both nations had gained
experience in counterinsurgency and jungle warfare during the [Malayan
Emergency](/wiki/Malayan_Emergency "Malayan Emergency") and World War II.
Their governments subscribed to the [Domino theory](/wiki/Domino_theory
"Domino theory"). New Zealand was however a reluctant participant. Officials
prophetically expected a foreign intervention to fail, were concerned that
they would be supporting a corrupt regime and didn't want to further stretch
their country's small military (which was already deployed to Malaysia).[356]
In the end though, a desire to prove their commitment to the ANZUS alliance
and discourage an American withdrawal from Southeast Asia necessitated a
military commitment. Australia began by sending advisors to Vietnam in 1962,
and combat troops were committed in 1965.[357] New Zealand began by sending a
detachment of engineers and an artillery battery, and then started sending
special forces and regular infantry which were attached to Australian
formations.[358] Australia's peak commitment was 7,672 combat troops and New
Zealand's 552. More than 60,000 Australian personnel were involved during the
course of the war, of which 521 were killed and more than 3,000 wounded.[359]
Approximately 3,500 New Zealanders served in Vietnam, with 37 killed and 187
wounded.[360] Most Australians and New Zealanders served in the [1st
Australian Task Force](/wiki/1st_Australian_Task_Force "1st Australian Task
Force") in [Phước Tuy Province](/wiki/Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Tuy_Province "Phước
Tuy Province").[357]

Australia's decades of experience from both the Malayan Emergency and its
[AATTV](/wiki/Australian_Army_Training_Team_Vietnam "Australian Army Training
Team Vietnam") role in 1962 saw a recognised need for true [counter-
insurgency](/wiki/Counter-insurgency "Counter-insurgency") which relied on
providing village-level security, establishing civilian trust and economic
incentives and improving [ARVN](/wiki/Army_of_the_Republic_of_Vietnam "Army of
the Republic of Vietnam") capabilities.[361] This had brought Australian
commanders to conflict with [William Westmoreland](/wiki/William_Westmoreland
"William Westmoreland")'s conventional attrition warfare approach since
Australian ground forces were required to follow US doctrine.[361]
Nevertheless, Australian forces and experience were generally the most capable
at the approach of [COIN](/wiki/Counter-insurgency "Counter-insurgency") and
had helped to train [Regional Forces](/wiki/South_Vietnamese_Regional_Force
"South Vietnamese Regional Force") despite being under significant doctrinal
constraints.[361]

#### Philippines

Some 10,450 [Filipino](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines") troops were dispatched
to South Vietnam. They were primarily engaged in medical and other civilian
pacification projects. These forces operated under the designation PHLCAG-V or
Philippine Civic Action Group-Vietnam. More noteworthy was the fact that the
naval base in [Subic Bay](/wiki/U.S._Naval_Base_Subic_Bay "U.S. Naval Base
Subic Bay") was used for the [U.S. Seventh Fleet](/wiki/U.S._Seventh_Fleet
"U.S. Seventh Fleet") from 1964 till the end of the war in 1975.[362][363] The
Navy base in Subic bay and the Air force base at [Clark](/wiki/Clark_Air_Base
"Clark Air Base") achieved maximum functionality during the war and supported
an estimated 80,000 locals in allied tertiary businesses from shoe making to
prostitution.[364]

#### Taiwan

Main article: [Republic of China in the Vietnam
War](/wiki/Republic_of_China_in_the_Vietnam_War "Republic of China in the
Vietnam War")

Since November 1967, [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") secretly operated a cargo
transport detachment to assist the United States and South Vietnam. Taiwan
also provided military training units for the South Vietnamese diving units,
later known as the Lien Doi Nguoi Nhai (LDMN) or "Frogman unit" in
English.[18] Military commandos from Taiwan were captured by North Vietnamese
forces three times trying to infiltrate North Vietnam.[18]

#### Brazil

[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"), under a U.S.-backed [military
regime](/wiki/Brazilian_military_government "Brazilian military government"),
officially supported the United States's position in South Vietnam and
contributed a medical team and supplies to the country—the only [Latin
American](/wiki/Latin_America "Latin America") country to do so.[19]

### Neutral and non-belligerent nations

#### Canada and the ICC

Main article: [Canada and the Vietnam War](/wiki/Canada_and_the_Vietnam_War
"Canada and the Vietnam War")

Canada, India and Poland constituted the [International Control
Commission](/wiki/International_Control_Commission "International Control
Commission"), which was supposed to monitor the 1954 ceasefire agreement.[365]
Officially, Canada did not have partisan involvement in the Vietnam War and
diplomatically it was "[non-belligerent](/wiki/Non-belligerent "Non-
belligerent")" though there is evidence to the contrary.[366][367] The
_Vietnam War_ entry in _[The Canadian
Encyclopedia](/wiki/The_Canadian_Encyclopedia "The Canadian Encyclopedia")_
asserts plainly that Canada's record on the truce commissions was a pro-Saigon
partisan one.[368]

## United Front for the Liberation of Oppressed Races (FULRO)

Main articles: [United Front for the Liberation of Oppressed
Races](/wiki/United_Front_for_the_Liberation_of_Oppressed_Races "United Front
for the Liberation of Oppressed Races") and [FULRO insurgency against
Vietnam](/wiki/FULRO_insurgency_against_Vietnam "FULRO insurgency against
Vietnam")

The ethnic minority peoples of South Vietnam like the
[Montagnards](/wiki/Degar "Degar") (Degar) in the [Central
Highlands](/wiki/Central_Highlands,_Vietnam "Central Highlands, Vietnam"),
Hindu and Muslim [Cham](/wiki/Cham_people "Cham people") and the Buddhist
[Khmer Krom](/wiki/Khmer_Krom "Khmer Krom") were actively recruited in the
war. There was an active strategy of recruitment and favorable treatment of
Montagnard tribes for the [Viet Cong](/wiki/Viet_Cong "Viet Cong"), as they
were pivotal for control of infiltration routes.[369] Some groups had split
off and formed together the [United Front for the Liberation of Oppressed
Races](/wiki/United_Front_for_the_Liberation_of_Oppressed_Races "United Front
for the Liberation of Oppressed Races") (French: Front Uni de Lutte des Races
Opprimées, acronym: FULRO) to fight for autonomy or independence. FULRO fought
against both the anti-Communist South Vietnamese and the Communist Viet Cong,
and then FULRO proceeded to fight against the unified [Socialist Republic of
Vietnam](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Vietnam "Socialist Republic of Vietnam")
after the fall of South Vietnam.

During the war, the South Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem began a program
to settle ethnic Vietnamese Kinh on Montagnard lands in the [Central
Highlands](/wiki/Central_Highlands_\(Vietnam\) "Central Highlands
\(Vietnam\)") region. This provoked a backlash from the Montagnards, some
joining the NLF as a result. The Cambodians under both the pro-China King
Sihanouk and the pro-American Lon Nol supported their fellow co-ethnic Khmer
Krom in South Vietnam, following an anti-ethnic Vietnamese policy. Following
Vietnamization many Montagnard groups and fighters were incorporated into the
[Vietnamese Rangers](/wiki/Vietnamese_Rangers "Vietnamese Rangers") as border
sentries.

War](/wiki/List_of_war_crimes#1955–1975:_Vietnam_War "List of war crimes"),
and [Vietnam War casualties](/wiki/Vietnam_War_casualties "Vietnam War
casualties")

"List of massacres in Vietnam")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/My_Lai_massacre.jpg/220px-
My_Lai_massacre.jpg)](/wiki/File:My_Lai_massacre.jpg)

A large number of [war crimes](/wiki/War_crimes "War crimes") took place
during the Vietnam War. War crimes were committed by both sides during the
conflict and included rape, massacres of civilians, bombings of civilian
targets,
[terrorism](/wiki/Viet_Cong_and_PAVN_strategy,_organization_and_structure#VC/NVA_use_of_terror
"Viet Cong and PAVN strategy, organization and structure"), the widespread use
of torture and the murder of [prisoners of war](/wiki/Prisoners_of_war
"Prisoners of war"). Additional common crimes included theft, arson, and the
destruction of property not warranted by [military
necessity](/wiki/Military_necessity "Military necessity").[370]

### Allied war crimes

See also: [Winter Soldier Investigation](/wiki/Winter_Soldier_Investigation
"Winter Soldier Investigation"), [Vietnam War Crimes Working
Group](/wiki/Vietnam_War_Crimes_Working_Group "Vietnam War Crimes Working
Group"), and [Tiger Force](/wiki/Tiger_Force "Tiger Force")

In 1968, the [Vietnam War Crimes Working
Group](/wiki/Vietnam_War_Crimes_Working_Group "Vietnam War Crimes Working
Group") (VWCWG) was established by the [Pentagon](/wiki/The_Pentagon "The
Pentagon") [task force](/wiki/Task_force "Task force") set up in the wake of
the [My Lai Massacre](/wiki/My_Lai_Massacre "My Lai Massacre"), to attempt to
ascertain the veracity of emerging claims of [war crimes by U.S. armed
forces](/wiki/War_crimes_by_U.S._armed_forces "War crimes by U.S. armed
forces") in Vietnam, during the Vietnam War period. A probable war-crime which
was neither investigated or brought to charge was the [Thuy Bo
massacre](/wiki/Thuy_Bo_massacre "Thuy Bo massacre") while the [Son Thang
massacre](/wiki/Son_Thang_massacre "Son Thang massacre") was one that
warranted investigation with its perpetrators court-martial and serving less
than a year of prison.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Vietconginterrogation1967.jpg/220px-
Vietconginterrogation1967.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietconginterrogation1967.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vietconginterrogation1967.jpg "Enlarge")

A suspected Viet Cong prisoner captured in 1967 by the U.S. Army awaits
interrogation. He has been placed in a [stress position](/wiki/Stress_position
"Stress position") by tying a board between his arms.

Of the portion of war-crimes which were reported to military authorities,
sworn statements by witnesses and status reports indicated that 320 war-crimes
incidents had a factual basis.[371] The substantiated cases included 7
massacres between 1967 and 1971 in which at least 137 civilians were killed;
seventy eight further attacks targeting non-combatants resulting in at least
57 deaths, 56 wounded and 15 sexually assaulted; one hundred and forty-one
cases of U.S. soldiers torturing civilian detainees or prisoners of war with
fists, sticks, bats, water or electric shock.[371] Rummel estimated that
American forces committed around 5,500 intentional [democidal](/wiki/Democide
"Democide") [killings](/wiki/Massacre "Massacre") between 1960 and 1972, from
a range of between 4,000 and 10,000 killed based on two sources published
while the war was ongoing.[372] Journalism in the ensuing years has documented
large numbers of overlooked and uninvestigated war crimes involving every army
division that was active in Vietnam,[371][373] with one prominent non-
investigated war-crime being the [Tiger Force](/wiki/Tiger_Force "Tiger
Force") atrocities.[374]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Viet_nam_Tragedy.jpg/220px-
Viet_nam_Tragedy.jpg)](/wiki/File:Viet_nam_Tragedy.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Viet_nam_Tragedy.jpg "Enlarge")

Napalm burn victims during the war being treated at the [67th Combat Support
Hospital](/wiki/67th_Combat_Support_Hospital_\(United_States\) "67th Combat
Support Hospital \(United States\)")

The establishment of numerous [free-fire zones](/wiki/Free-fire_zone "Free-
fire zone") by U.S. forces as a tactic to prevent Viet Cong fighters from
sheltering in South Vietnamese villages.[375] Such practice, which involved
the assumption that any individual appearing in the designated zones was an
enemy combatant that could be freely targeted by weapons, is regarded by
journalist Lewis M. Simons as "a severe violation of the laws of war".[376]
[Nick Turse](/wiki/Nick_Turse "Nick Turse"), in his 2013 book, _Kill Anything
that Moves_ , argues that a relentless drive toward higher body counts, a
widespread use of free-fire zones, rules of engagement where civilians who ran
from soldiers or helicopters could be viewed as Viet Cong, and a widespread
disdain for Vietnamese civilians led to massive civilian casualties and
endemic war crimes inflicted by U.S. troops.[377] One example cited by Turse
is [Operation Speedy Express](/wiki/Operation_Speedy_Express "Operation Speedy
Express"), an operation by the 9th Infantry Division, which was described by
[John Paul Vann](/wiki/John_Paul_Vann "John Paul Vann") as, in effect, "many
My Lais".[377] A report by _Newsweek_ magazine suggested that at minimum 5,000
civilians may have been killed during six months of the operation, as there
was around 748 recovered weapons.[378]
