[Tam Tòa Church](/wiki/Tam_T%C3%B2a_Church "Tam Tòa Church") in [Đồng
Hới](/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng_H%E1%BB%9Bi "Đồng Hới"), [Quảng Bình
Province](/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_B%C3%ACnh_Province "Quảng Bình Province"). Most
of the city and the church was flattened during B-52 bombings in 1965.

R.J. Rummel estimated that 39,000 were killed by South Vietnam during the
Diem-era in [democide](/wiki/Democide "Democide") from a range of between
16,000 and 167,000 South Vietnamese civilians; for 1964 to 1975, Rummel
estimated a total of 50,000 killed in democide, from a range of between 42,000
and 128,000. Thus, the total for 1954 to 1975 is 81,000, from a range of
between 57,000 and 284,000 deaths caused by South Vietnam.[379] Benjamin
Valentino attributes possibly 110,000–310,000 "counter-guerrilla mass
killings" of non-combatants to U.S. and South Vietnamese forces during the
war.[380] An estimated 26,000 to 41,000 civilian members of the
[PRG](/wiki/Provisional_Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Republic_of_South_Vietnam
"Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South
Vietnam")/[NLF](/wiki/Viet_Cong "Viet Cong") termed "VC Infrastructure" were
killed during the [Phoenix Program](/wiki/Phoenix_Program "Phoenix Program"),
by US and South Vietnamese intelligence and security, with an unknown number
being innocent civilians.[381][382][383]

Torture and ill-treatment were frequently applied by the South Vietnamese to
POWs as well as civilian prisoners.[384][385] During their visit to the [Con
Son Prison](/wiki/Con_Dao_Prison "Con Dao Prison") in 1970, U.S. Congressmen
[Augustus F. Hawkins](/wiki/Augustus_F._Hawkins "Augustus F. Hawkins") and
[William R. Anderson](/wiki/William_Anderson_\(naval_officer\) "William
Anderson \(naval officer\)") witnessed detainees either confined in minute
"tiger cages" or chained to their cells, and provided with poor-quality food.
A group of American doctors inspecting the prison in the same year found many
inmates suffering symptoms resulting from forced immobility and torture.[384]
During their visits to transit detention facilities under American
administration in 1968 and 1969, the [International Red
Cross](/wiki/International_Red_Cross_and_Red_Crescent_Movement "International
Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement") recorded many cases of torture and
inhumane treatment before the captives were handed over to South Vietnamese
authorities.[386] Torture was conducted by the South Vietnamese government in
collusion with the CIA.[387][388]

South Korean forces were also accused of war crimes as well. One documented
event was the [Phong Nhị and Phong Nhất
massacre](/wiki/Phong_Nh%E1%BB%8B_and_Phong_Nh%E1%BA%A5t_massacre "Phong Nhị
and Phong Nhất massacre") where the [2nd Marine
Brigade](/wiki/2nd_Marine_Division_\(South_Korea\) "2nd Marine Division
\(South Korea\)") of the [South Korean Army](/wiki/South_Korean_Army "South
Korean Army") reportedly killed 69–79 civilians on 12 February 1968 in Phong
Nhị and Phong Nhất village, [Điện Bàn
District](/wiki/%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_B%C3%A0n_District "Điện Bàn District") of
[Quảng Nam Province](/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Nam_Province "Quảng Nam Province") in
South Vietnam.[389] South Korean forces are also accused of perpetrating other
massacres, namely: [Bình Hòa massacre](/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_H%C3%B2a_massacre "Bình
Hòa massacre"), [Binh Tai Massacre](/wiki/Binh_Tai_Massacre "Binh Tai
Massacre") and [Hà My massacre](/wiki/H%C3%A0_My_massacre "Hà My massacre")
alongside the [Bình An/Tây Vinh
massacre](/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_An/T%C3%A2y_Vinh_massacre "Bình An/Tây Vinh
massacre").

### North Vietnamese and Viet Cong war crimes

Main article: [Viet Cong and PAVN strategy, organization and structure §
VC/NVA use of
terror](/wiki/Viet_Cong_and_PAVN_strategy,_organization_and_structure#VC/NVA_use_of_terror
"Viet Cong and PAVN strategy, organization and structure")

See also: [Cambodian Civil War § War
Crimes](/wiki/Cambodian_Civil_War#War_Crimes "Cambodian Civil War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Hue_Massacre_Interment.jpg/220px-
Hue_Massacre_Interment.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hue_Massacre_Interment.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hue_Massacre_Interment.jpg "Enlarge")

Interment of victims of the Huế Massacre

Ami Pedahzur has written that "the overall volume and lethality of Viet Cong
[terrorism](/wiki/Terrorism "Terrorism") rivals or exceeds all but a handful
of terrorist campaigns waged over the last third of the twentieth century",
based on the definition of terrorists as a non-state actor, and examining
targeted killings and civilian deaths which are estimated at over 18,000 from
1966 to 1969.[390] The US Department of Defense estimates the VC/NVA had
conducted 36,000 murders and almost 58,000 kidnappings from 1967 to 1972, c.
1973.[391] Statistics for 1968–72 suggest that "about 80 percent of the
terrorist victims were ordinary civilians and only about 20 percent were
government officials, policemen, members of the self-defence forces or
pacification cadres."[392] Benjamin Valentino attributes 45,000–80,000
"terrorist mass killings" of non-combatants to the Viet Cong during the
war.[380] Viet Cong tactics included the frequent mortaring of civilians in
refugee camps, and the placing of mines on highways frequented by villagers
taking their goods to urban markets. Some mines were set only to go off after
heavy vehicle passage, causing extensive slaughter aboard packed civilian
buses.[393]

Notable Viet Cong atrocities include the [massacre of over 3,000 unarmed
civilians](/wiki/Massacre_at_Hu%E1%BA%BF "Massacre at Huế") at
[Huế](/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF "Huế") during the [Tet Offensive](/wiki/Tet_Offensive
"Tet Offensive") and the killing of 252 civilians during the [Đắk Sơn
massacre](/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%AFk_S%C6%A1n_massacre "Đắk Sơn massacre").[394]
155,000 refugees fleeing the final North Vietnamese [Spring
Offensive](/wiki/1975_Spring_Offensive "1975 Spring Offensive") were reported
to have been killed or abducted on the road to [Tuy Hòa](/wiki/Tuy_H%C3%B2a
"Tuy Hòa") in 1975.[395] According to Rummel, North Vietnamese and Viet Cong
troops killed 164,000 civilians in democide between 1954 and 1975 in South
Vietnam, from a range of between 106,000 and 227,000 (50,000 of which were
reportedly killed by shelling and mortar on ARVN forces during the retreat to
Tuy Hoa).[396] North Vietnam was also known for its abusive treatment of
American POWs, most notably in [Hỏa Lò
Prison](/wiki/H%E1%BB%8Fa_L%C3%B2_Prison "Hỏa Lò Prison") (aka the _Hanoi
Hilton_), where [torture was employed to extract
confessions](/wiki/Forced_confession "Forced confession").[397]

## Women in the Vietnam War

### American nurses

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Da_Nang%2C_South_Vietnam...United_States_Navy_nurse_Lieutenant_Commander_Joan_Brouilette_checks_the_condition_of_Pfc...._-_NARA_-_558531.jpg/220px-
Da_Nang%2C_South_Vietnam...United_States_Navy_nurse_Lieutenant_Commander_Joan_Brouilette_checks_the_condition_of_Pfc...._-_NARA_-_558531.jpg)](/wiki/File:Da_Nang,_South_Vietnam...United_States_Navy_nurse_Lieutenant_Commander_Joan_Brouilette_checks_the_condition_of_Pfc...._-_NARA_-_558531.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Da_Nang,_South_Vietnam...United_States_Navy_nurse_Lieutenant_Commander_Joan_Brouilette_checks_the_condition_of_Pfc...._-_NARA_-_558531.jpg
"Enlarge")

Da Nang, South Vietnam, 1968

During the Vietnam War, American women served on active duty doing a variety
of jobs. Early in 1963, the [Army Nurse
Corps](/wiki/Army_Nurse_Corps_\(United_States\) "Army Nurse Corps \(United
States\)") (ANC) launched Operation Nightingale, an intensive effort to
recruit nurses to serve in Vietnam.[398] [First
Lieutenant](/wiki/First_Lieutenant "First Lieutenant") Sharon Lane was the
only female military nurse to be killed by enemy gunfire during the war, on 8
June 1969.[399] One civilian doctor, [Eleanor Ardel
Vietti](/wiki/Eleanor_Ardel_Vietti "Eleanor Ardel Vietti"), who was captured
by Viet Cong on May 30, 1962, in [Buôn Ma
Thuột](/wiki/Bu%C3%B4n_Ma_Thu%E1%BB%99t "Buôn Ma Thuột"), remains the only
American woman unaccounted for from the Vietnam War.[400][401][402]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Second_Lieutenant_Kathleen_M._Sullivan_treats_a_Vietnamese_child_during_Operation_MED_CAP%2C_a_U.S._Air_Force_civic..._-_NARA_-_542331.jpg/220px-
Second_Lieutenant_Kathleen_M._Sullivan_treats_a_Vietnamese_child_during_Operation_MED_CAP%2C_a_U.S._Air_Force_civic..._-_NARA_-_542331.jpg)](/wiki/File:Second_Lieutenant_Kathleen_M._Sullivan_treats_a_Vietnamese_child_during_Operation_MED_CAP,_a_U.S._Air_Force_civic..._-_NARA_-_542331.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Second_Lieutenant_Kathleen_M._Sullivan_treats_a_Vietnamese_child_during_Operation_MED_CAP,_a_U.S._Air_Force_civic..._-_NARA_-_542331.jpg
"Enlarge")

A nurse treats a Vietnamese child, 1967

Although a small number of women were assigned to combat zones, they were
never allowed directly in the field of battle. The women who served in the
military were solely volunteers. They faced a plethora of challenges, one of
which was the relatively small number of female soldiers. Living in a male-
dominated environment created tensions between the sexes. By 1973,
approximately 7,500 women had served in Vietnam in the Southeast Asian
theater.[403] American women serving in Vietnam were subject to societal
stereotypes. To address this problem, the ANC released advertisements
portraying women in the ANC as "proper, professional and well protected." This
effort to highlight the positive aspects of a nursing career reflected the
feminism of the 1960s–1970s in the United States. Although female military
nurses lived in a heavily male environment, very few cases of sexual
harassment were ever reported.[404]

ARVN_Pharmacist.jpg)

### Vietnamese women

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Female_Vietcong_Guerrilla.jpg/220px-
Female_Vietcong_Guerrilla.jpg)](/wiki/File:Female_Vietcong_Guerrilla.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Female_Vietcong_Guerrilla.jpg "Enlarge")

Female [Viet Cong](/wiki/Viet_Cong "Viet Cong") guerrilla in combat

Unlike the American women who went to Vietnam, both South and North Vietnamese
women were enlisted and fought in the combat zone. Women were enlisted in both
the North Vietnamese Army (NVA) and the Viet Cong guerrilla insurgent force in
South Vietnam, many joining due to the promises of female equality and a
greater social role within society.[405][406] Some women also served for the
North Vietnamese and Viet Cong intelligence services. The deputy military
commander of the
[PLAF](/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Armed_Forces_of_South_Vietnam "People's
Liberation Armed Forces of South Vietnam"), the armed wing of the [Viet
Cong](/wiki/Viet_Cong "Viet Cong"), was a female general [Nguyễn Thị
Định](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh "Nguyễn Thị Định").
All female units were present throughout the entirety of the war, ranging from
front-line combat troops to anti-air units, scout and reconnaissance units and
others providing intelligence.[407] There was female combat squads present at
the Cu Chi theatre.[408] alongside the Battle of Hue.[409] Large numbers of
women volunteered in addition throughout North Vietnam, manning anti-aircraft
batteries, providing village security as well as serving in logistics on the
[Ho Chi Minh trail](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_trail "Ho Chi Minh trail").[407][410]
Many more women would be embedded with troops on the front-line, serving as
doctors and medical personnel. [Đặng Thùy
Trâm](/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%B7ng_Th%C3%B9y_Tr%C3%A2m "Đặng Thùy Trâm") became
renown after her diary was published following her death. The Foreign Minister
for the [National Liberation Front](/wiki/Viet_Cong "Viet Cong") and later the
[PRG](/wiki/Provisional_Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Republic_of_South_Vietnam
"Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam") was
also a woman, [Nguyễn Thị Bình](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_B%C3%ACnh
"Nguyễn Thị Bình").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/%C4%90%E1%BB%81n_th%E1%BB%9D_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh.jpg/220px-%C4%90%E1%BB%81n_th%E1%BB%9D_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C4%90%E1%BB%81n_th%E1%BB%9D_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%C4%90%E1%BB%81n_th%E1%BB%9D_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh.jpg
"Enlarge")

Memorial temple to [Nguyễn Thị
Định](/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Th%E1%BB%8B_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh "Nguyễn Thị Định")
and the female volunteers of the
[PLAF](/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Armed_Forces_of_South_Vietnam "People's
Liberation Armed Forces of South Vietnam") whom she commanded. They came to
call themselves the "Long-Haired Army".

In South Vietnam, many women voluntarily served in the [ARVN](/wiki/ARVN
"ARVN")'s Women's Armed Force Corps (WAFC) and various other Women's corps in
the military. Some, like in the WAFC, fought in combat with other soldiers.
Others served as nurses and doctors in the battlefield and in military
hospitals, or served in South Vietnam or America's intelligence agencies.
During [Diệm](/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m "Ngô Đình Diệm")'s
presidency, [Madame Nhu](/wiki/Madame_Nhu "Madame Nhu") was the commander of
the WAFC.[411] Many women joined provincial and voluntary village-level
militia in the _People 's Self Defense Force_ as part of the [South Vietnamese
Popular Force](/wiki/South_Vietnamese_Popular_Force "South Vietnamese Popular
Force") especially during the ARVN expansions later in the war.

The war saw more than one million rural people migrate or flee the fighting in
the South Vietnamese countryside to the cities, especially Saigon. Among the
internal refugees were many young women who became the ubiquitous "bargirls"
of wartime South Vietnam "hawking her wares—be that cigarettes, liquor, or
herself" to American and allied soldiers.[412] American bases were ringed by
bars and brothels.[413]

8,040 Vietnamese women came to the United States as war brides between 1964
and 1975.[414] Many mixed-blood [Amerasian](/wiki/Amerasian "Amerasian")
children were left behind when their American fathers returned to the United
States after their tour of duty in South Vietnam. 26,000 of them were
permitted to immigrate to the United States in the 1980s and 1990s.[415]

### Female journalists

The Vietnam War also saw women play a prominent role as front-line reporters
in the conflict, directly reporting on the conflict as it occurred.[416] A
number of women volunteered on the North Vietnamese side as embedded
journalists including author [Lê Minh Khuê](/wiki/L%C3%AA_Minh_Khu%C3%AA "Lê
Minh Khuê") embedded with PAVN forces,[417] including on the [Ho Chi Minh
trail](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_trail "Ho Chi Minh trail") as well as on combat
fronts.[418] A number of prominent Western journalists were also involved in
covering the war, with [Dickey Chapelle](/wiki/Dickey_Chapelle "Dickey
Chapelle") being among the first as well as the first American female reporter
killed in a war. The French-speaking Australian journalist [Kate
Webb](/wiki/Kate_Webb "Kate Webb") was captured alongside a photographer and
others by the Viet Cong in Cambodia and travelled into Laos with them,
released back into Cambodia afterwards after 23 days of captivity.[419] She
would be the first Western journalist to be captured and released, as well as
cover the perspective of the Viet Cong in her memoir _On The Other Side._
Another French-speaking journalist [Catherine Leroy](/wiki/Catherine_Leroy
"Catherine Leroy") was briefly captured and released by North Vietnamese
forces during the [Battle of Huế](/wiki/Battle_of_Hu%E1%BA%BF "Battle of
Huế"), capturing some of the famous photos from the battles that would appear
on the cover of _Life Magazine_.[420]

## Black servicemen in Vietnam

See also: [Civil rights movement](/wiki/Civil_rights_movement "Civil rights
movement") and [Military history of African Americans § Vietnam
War](/wiki/Military_history_of_African_Americans#Vietnam_War "Military history
of African Americans")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Haeberlewounded.jpg/190px-
Haeberlewounded.jpg)](/wiki/File:Haeberlewounded.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Haeberlewounded.jpg "Enlarge")

A wounded [African-American](/wiki/African_Americans "African Americans")
soldier being carried away, 1968

The experience of American military personnel of African origin during the
Vietnam War had received significant attention. For example, the website
"African-American Involvement in the Vietnam War" compiles examples of such
coverage,[421] as does the print and broadcast work of journalist [Wallace
Terry](/wiki/Wallace_Terry "Wallace Terry").

Terry's book _Bloods: An Oral History of the Vietnam War by Black Veterans_
(1984), includes observations about the impact of the war on the black
community in general and on black servicemen specifically. Points he makes on
the latter topic include: the higher proportion of combat casualties in
Vietnam among African American servicemen than among American soldiers of
other races, the shift toward and different attitudes of black military
careerists versus black draftees, the discrimination encountered by black
servicemen "on the battlefield in decorations, promotion and duty assignments"
as well as their having to endure "the racial insults, cross-burnings and
Confederate flags of their white comrades"—and the experiences faced by black
soldiers stateside, during the war and after America's withdrawal.[422] Civil
rights leaders protested the disproportionate casualties and the over-
representation in hazardous duty and combat roles experienced by African
American servicemen, prompting reforms that were implemented beginning in
1967–68. As a result, by the war's completion in 1975, black casualties had
declined to 12.5% of US combat deaths, approximately equal to percentage of
draft-eligible black men, though still slightly higher than the 10% who served
in the military.[423]

## Weapons

Main article: [Weapons of the Vietnam War](/wiki/Weapons_of_the_Vietnam_War
"Weapons of the Vietnam War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/HoChiMinhTrail003.jpg/170px-
HoChiMinhTrail003.jpg)](/wiki/File:HoChiMinhTrail003.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:HoChiMinhTrail003.jpg "Enlarge")

Guerillas assemble shells and rockets delivered along the Ho Chi Minh Trail.

During the early stages the Viet Cong mainly sustained itself with captured
arms, often of American manufacture[424] or crude, self-made weapons [425] and
[shotguns](/wiki/Shotgun "Shotgun") made of galvanized pipes.[426] Most arms
were captured from poorly defended ARVN militia outposts.[427] In 1967, all
Viet Cong battalions were reequipped with arms of Soviet design such as the
[AK-47](/wiki/AK-47 "AK-47") assault rifle and the [RPG-2](/wiki/RPG-2
"RPG-2") anti-tank weapon.[428] Their weapons were principally of Chinese[429]
or Soviet manufacture.[430] The period up to the conventional phase in the
1970, the Viet Cong and NVA were primarily limited to mortars 81-mm mortars,
recoil-less rifles and small-arms and had significantly lighter equipment and
firepower in comparison with the US arsenal, relying on ambushes alongside
superior stealth, planning, marksmanship and small-unit tactics to face the
disproportionate US technological advantage.[431]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/M41-walker-bulldog-
tank.jpg/220px-M41-walker-bulldog-tank.jpg)](/wiki/File:M41-walker-bulldog-
tank.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:M41-walker-bulldog-tank.jpg "Enlarge")

[M41 Walker Bulldog](/wiki/M41_Walker_Bulldog "M41 Walker Bulldog"), the
primary tank of the US and ARVN

After the Tet Offensive, many North Vietnamese units incorporated [light
tanks](/wiki/Light_tank "Light tank") such as the [Type 62](/wiki/Type_62
"Type 62") [Type 59 tank](/wiki/Type_59_tank "Type 59 tank").,
[BTR-60](/wiki/BTR-60 "BTR-60"), [Type 60
artillery](/wiki/D-74_122_mm_field_gun "D-74 122 mm field gun"), [amphibious
tanks](/wiki/Amphibious_vehicle "Amphibious vehicle") (such as the
[PT-76](/wiki/PT-76 "PT-76")) and integrated into new war doctrines as a
mobile combined-arms force.[432] The North Vietnamese started receiving
experimental Soviet weapons against ARVN forces including [MANPADS](/wiki/Man-
portable_air-defense_system "Man-portable air-defense system") [9K32
Strela-2](/wiki/9K32_Strela-2 "9K32 Strela-2"), and [anti-tank
missiles](/wiki/Anti-tank_missile "Anti-tank missile"), [9M14
Malyutka](/wiki/9M14_Malyutka "9M14 Malyutka").[93] By 1975 they had fully
transformed from the strategy of mobile light-infantry and using the people's
war concept used against the United States.[432]

The US service rifle was initially the [M14](/wiki/M14_rifle "M14 rifle")
until it was replaced by the [M16 rifle](/wiki/M16_rifle "M16 rifle"). For a
period, the gun suffered from a jamming flaw.[433] According to a
congressional report, the jamming was due to inadequate testing and reflected
a decision for which the safety of soldiers was a secondary
consideration.[434] That issue was solved in early 1968 with the issuance of
the M16A1 that featured a chrome plated bore.[435] The [M60 machine
gun](/wiki/M60_machine_gun "M60 machine gun") was the main machine gun of the
US army at the time and many of them were put on helicopters, to provide
[suppressive fire](/wiki/Suppressive_fire "Suppressive fire"). The MAC-10
[machine pistol](/wiki/Machine_pistol "Machine pistol") was supplied to many
special forces troops in the midpoint of the war.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/UH-1D_helicopters_in_Vietnam_1966.jpg/220px-
UH-1D_helicopters_in_Vietnam_1966.jpg)](/wiki/File:UH-1D_helicopters_in_Vietnam_1966.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:UH-1D_helicopters_in_Vietnam_1966.jpg "Enlarge")

[UH-1D](/wiki/Bell_UH-1_Iroquois "Bell UH-1 Iroquois") helicopters airlift
members of a U.S. infantry regiment, 1966

Two aircraft which were prominent in the war were the [AC-130
"Spectre"](/wiki/Lockheed_AC-130 "Lockheed AC-130") Gunship and the
[UH-1](/wiki/UH-1 "UH-1") "Huey" gunship. The AC-130 was a heavily armed
[ground-attack aircraft](/wiki/Attack_aircraft "Attack aircraft") variant of
the [C-130 Hercules](/wiki/Lockheed_C-130_Hercules "Lockheed C-130 Hercules")
transport plane. The Huey is a [military helicopter](/wiki/Military_helicopter
"Military helicopter") powered by a single, [turboshaft](/wiki/Turboshaft
"Turboshaft") engine, and approximately 7,000 UH-1 aircraft saw service in
Vietnam.The US' heavily armored, 90 mm [M48A3 Patton tank](/wiki/M48_Patton
"M48 Patton") saw extensive action during the Vietnam War and over 600 were
deployed with US Forces. Ground forces also had access to
[B-52](/wiki/Boeing_B-52_Stratofortress "Boeing B-52 Stratofortress") and [F-4
Phantom II](/wiki/McDonnell_Douglas_F-4_Phantom_II "McDonnell Douglas F-4
Phantom II") and others to launch [napalm](/wiki/Napalm "Napalm"), [white
phosphorus](/wiki/White_phosphorus_munitions "White phosphorus munitions"),
[tear gas](/wiki/Tear_gas "Tear gas") and [chemical
weapons](/wiki/Chemical_weapon "Chemical weapon"),[precision-guided
munition](/wiki/Precision-guided_munition "Precision-guided munition") and
[cluster bombs](/wiki/Cluster_bomb "Cluster bomb").[436]

### Radio communications

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/North_Vietnamese_SA-2.jpg/220px-
North_Vietnamese_SA-2.jpg)](/wiki/File:North_Vietnamese_SA-2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:North_Vietnamese_SA-2.jpg "Enlarge")

North Vietnamese SAM crew in front of SA-2 launcher. The Soviet Union provided
North Vietnam with considerable anti-air defence around installations.

The Vietnam War was the first conflict where U.S. forces had [secure
voice](/wiki/Secure_voice "Secure voice") communication equipment available at
the tactical level. The [National Security
Agency](/wiki/National_Security_Agency "National Security Agency") ran a crash
program to provide U.S. forces with a family of security equipment code named
[NESTOR](/wiki/NESTOR_\(encryption\) "NESTOR \(encryption\)"), fielding 17,000
units initially. Eventually 30,000 units were produced. However limitations of
the units, including poor voice quality, reduced range, annoying time delays
and logistical support issues led to only one unit in ten being used.[437]:Vol
II, p. 43 While many in the U.S. military believed that the Viet Cong and NVA
would not be able to exploit insecure communications, interrogation of
captured communication intelligence units showed they were able to understand
the jargon and codes used in realtime and were often able to warn their side
of impending U.S. actions.[437]:Vol II, pp. 4, 10

Bombs_from_B-52_Arc_Light_strike_exploding.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bombs_from_B-52_Arc_Light_strike_exploding.jpg)

Bombs being dropped by the [B-52 Stratofortress](/wiki/B-52_Stratofortress

The U.S. dropped over 7 million tons of bombs on Indochina during the war—more
than triple the 2.1 million tons of bombs the U.S. dropped on Europe and Asia
during all of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), and more than
ten times the amount dropped by the U.S. during the [Korean
War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War"). 500 thousand tons were dropped on
Cambodia, 1 million tons were dropped on North Vietnam, and 4 million tons
were dropped on South Vietnam. On a per capita basis, the 2 million tons
dropped on Laos make it the most heavily bombed country in history; _[The New
York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ noted this was
"nearly a ton for every person in Laos."[438] Due to the particularly heavy
impact of [cluster bombs](/wiki/Cluster_bombs "Cluster bombs") during this
war, Laos was a strong advocate of the [Convention on Cluster
Munitions](/wiki/Convention_on_Cluster_Munitions "Convention on Cluster
Munitions") to ban the weapons, and was host to the First Meeting of States
Parties to the convention in November 2010.[439]

Former U.S. Air Force official Earl Tilford has recounted "repeated bombing
runs of a lake in central Cambodia. The B-52s literally dropped their payloads
in the lake": The Air Force ran many missions of this kind for the purpose of
securing additional funding during budget negotiations, so the amount of
tonnage expended does not directly correlate with the resulting damage.[440]

## Aftermath

### Events in Southeast Asia

Further information: [Mayaguez incident](/wiki/Mayaguez_incident "Mayaguez
incident") and [Indochina refugee crisis](/wiki/Indochina_refugee_crisis
"Indochina refugee crisis")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/35_Vietnamese_boat_people_2.JPEG/170px-35_Vietnamese_boat_people_2.JPEG)](/wiki/File:35_Vietnamese_boat_people_2.JPEG)

[](/wiki/File:35_Vietnamese_boat_people_2.JPEG "Enlarge")

Vietnamese refugees fleeing Vietnam, 1984

On 2 July 1976, North and South Vietnam were merged to form the [Socialist
Republic of Vietnam](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Vietnam "Socialist Republic
of Vietnam").[441] Despite speculation that the victorious North Vietnamese
would, in President Nixon's words, "massacre the civilians there [South
Vietnam] by the millions," there is a widespread consensus that no mass
executions in fact took place.[442] However, in the years following the war, a
vast number of South Vietnamese was sent to [re-education
camps](/wiki/Reeducation_camp "Reeducation camp") where many endured torture,
starvation, and disease while being forced to perform hard labor.[443][444]
According to Amnesty International Report 1979, this figure varied
considerably depend on different observers: "[...] included such figures as
"50,000 to 80,000" (Le Monde, 19 April 1978), "150,000" (Reuter from Bien Hoa,
2 November 1977), "150,000 to 200,000" (Washington Post, 20 December 1978),
and "300,000" (Agence France Presse from Hanoi, 12 February 1978)."[445] These
large variation may be due to "Some estimates may include not only detainees
but also people sent from the cities to the countryside." According to a
native observer, there were 443.360 people who had to register for a period in
re-education camps in Saigon alone, some of them were released after a few
days, while others stayed there for more than a decade.[446]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/B52_CRASH_WRECKAGE_AT_HUU_TIEP_LAKE_HA_NOI_FEB_2012_%286887035292%29.jpg/170px-B52_CRASH_WRECKAGE_AT_HUU_TIEP_LAKE_HA_NOI_FEB_2012_%286887035292%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:B52_CRASH_WRECKAGE_AT_HUU_TIEP_LAKE_HA_NOI_FEB_2012_\(6887035292\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:B52_CRASH_WRECKAGE_AT_HUU_TIEP_LAKE_HA_NOI_FEB_2012_\(6887035292\).jpg
"Enlarge")

A B-52 wreckage site near the [B-52 Victory Museum,
Hanoi](/wiki/B-52_Victory_Museum,_Hanoi "B-52 Victory Museum, Hanoi"). Downed
during [Operation Linebacker II](/wiki/Operation_Linebacker_II "Operation
Linebacker II"), its remains have turned into a war monument.

[Gabriel García Márquez](/wiki/Gabriel_Garc%C3%ADa_M%C3%A1rquez "Gabriel
García Márquez"), a [Nobel Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") winner
writer, described South Vietnam as a "False paradise" after the war, when he
visited this country in 1980: "The cost of this delirium was stupefying:
360,000 people mutilated, a million widows, 500,000 prostitutes, 500,000 drug
addicts, a million tuberculous and more than a million soldiers of the old
regime, impossible to completely rehabilitate into a new society. Ten percent
of the population of [Ho Chi Minh City](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City "Ho Chi Minh
City") was suffering from serious venereal diseases when the war ended, and
there were 4 million illiterates throughout the South."[447] The US used its
[security council veto](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_veto_power
"United Nations Security Council veto power") to block Vietnam's recognition
by the United Nations three times, an obstacle to the country receiving
international aid.[448]

By 1975, the Viet Minh had lost influence over the Cambodian communists.[449]
[Phnom Penh](/wiki/Phnom_Penh "Phnom Penh"), the capital of Cambodia, fell to
the Khmer Rouge on 17 April 1975. Under the leadership of [Pol
Pot](/wiki/Pol_Pot "Pol Pot"), the Khmer Rouge would eventually [kill 1–3
million Cambodians](/wiki/Cambodian_genocide "Cambodian genocide") out of a
population of around 8 million, in one of the [bloodiest genocides in
history](/wiki/List_of_genocides_by_death_toll "List of genocides by death
toll").[73][450][451][452]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Bombed_Buddha_-
_panoramio.jpg/170px-Bombed_Buddha_-
_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bombed_Buddha_-_panoramio.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bombed_Buddha_-_panoramio.jpg "Enlarge")

A bombed Buddha statute in Laos. The U.S. bombing campaigns saw the country
becoming the single most bombed country in history.

The relationship between Vietnam and Cambodia, then ruled by the [Khmer
Rouge](/wiki/Khmer_Rouge "Khmer Rouge") communist party, escalated right after
the end of the war, April 1975. In response to the Khmer Rouge taking over Phu
Quoc on 17 April and Tho Chu on 4 May 1975, and was thought to be their
responsibility for the disappearance of 500 Vietnamese natives on Tho Chu,
Vietnam launched a counterattack to take back these islands.[453] After
several failed attempt to negotiate from both sides, in 1978, Vietnam invaded
Democratic Kampuchea (Cambodia) and outed the Khmer Rouge, who were being
supported by China, in the [Cambodian–Vietnamese
War](/wiki/Cambodian%E2%80%93Vietnamese_War "Cambodian–Vietnamese War"). In
response, China invaded Vietnam in 1979. The two countries fought a brief
border war, known as the [Sino-Vietnamese War](/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_War
"Sino-Vietnamese War"). From 1978 to 1979, some 450,000 ethnic
[Chinese](/wiki/Hoa_people "Hoa people") left Vietnam by boat as refugees or
were expelled.

The [Pathet Lao](/wiki/Pathet_Lao "Pathet Lao") overthrew the [monarchy of
Laos](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos "Kingdom of Laos") in December 1975, establishing
the [Lao People's Democratic
Republic](/wiki/Lao_People%27s_Democratic_Republic "Lao People's Democratic
Republic") under the leadership of a member of the royal family,
[Souphanouvong](/wiki/Souphanouvong "Souphanouvong"). The change in regime was
"quite peaceful, a sort of Asiatic '[velvet
revolution](/wiki/Velvet_revolution "Velvet revolution")'"—although 30,000
former officials were sent to reeducation camps, often enduring harsh
conditions for several years. The conflict between [Hmong](/wiki/Hmong_people
"Hmong people") rebels and the Pathet Lao [continued](/wiki/Insurgency_in_Laos
"Insurgency in Laos") in isolated pockets.[454]

The millions of [cluster bombs](/wiki/Cluster_bombs "Cluster bombs") the US
dropped on Southeast Asia rendered the landscape hazardous. In Laos alone,
some 80 million bombs failed to explode and remain scattered throughout the
country, rendering vast swathes of land impossible to cultivate and killing or
maiming 50 Laotians every year.[455] It is estimated that the explosive that
still remains buried in the ground will not be removed entirely until the next
few centuries.[456] Over 3 million people left Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia in
the [Indochina refugee crisis](/wiki/Indochina_refugee_crisis "Indochina
refugee crisis"). Most Asian countries were unwilling to accept these
refugees, many of whom fled by boat and were known as [boat
people](/wiki/Boat_people "Boat people").[457] Between 1975 and 1998, an
estimated 1.2 million [refugees](/wiki/Refugee "Refugee") from Vietnam and
other Southeast Asian countries resettled in the United States, while Canada,
Australia, and France resettled over 500,000. China accepted 250,000
people.[458] Of all the countries of Indochina, Laos experienced the largest
refugee flight in proportional terms, as 300,000 people out of a total
population of 3 million crossed the border into Thailand. Included among their
ranks were "about 90 percent" of Laos's "intellectuals, technicians, and
officials."[459] An estimated 200,000 to 400,000 [Vietnamese boat
people](/wiki/Vietnamese_boat_people "Vietnamese boat people") died at sea,
according to the [United Nations High Commissioner for
Refugees](/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees "United Nations
High Commissioner for Refugees").[460]

Le_mus%C3%A9e_des_Souvenirs_de_guerre_%28H%C3%B4_Chi_Minh_Ville%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Le_mus%C3%A9e_des_Souvenirs_de_guerre_\(H%C3%B4_Chi_Minh_Ville\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Le_mus%C3%A9e_des_Souvenirs_de_guerre_\(H%C3%B4_Chi_Minh_Ville\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Captured U.S.-supplied armored vehicles and artillery pieces

[Agent Orange](/wiki/Agent_Orange "Agent Orange") and similar chemical
substances used by the U.S. have also caused a considerable number of deaths
and injuries in the intervening years, including among the US Air Force crew
that handled them. Scientific reports have concluded that refugees exposed to
chemical sprays while in South Vietnam continued to experience pain in the
eyes and skin as well as gastrointestinal upsets. In one study, ninety-two
percent of participants suffered incessant fatigue; others reported [monstrous
births](/wiki/Monstrous_birth "Monstrous birth").[461] Meta-analyses of the
most current studies on the association between Agent Orange and birth defects
have concluded that there is a statistically significant correlation such that
having a parent who was exposed to Agent Orange at any point in their life
will increase one's likelihood of either possessing or acting as a genetic
carrier of birth defects.[462] The most common deformation appears to be
[spina bifida](/wiki/Spina_bifida "Spina bifida"). There is substantial
evidence that the birth defects carry on for three generations or more.[463]
In 2012, the United States and Vietnam began a cooperative cleaning up of the
toxic chemical on part of [Danang International
Airport](/wiki/Danang_International_Airport "Danang International Airport"),
marking the first time Washington has been involved in cleaning up Agent
Orange in Vietnam.[464]

### Effect on the United States

#### Views on the war

United States expenditures in South Vietnam (SVN) (1953–1974) Direct costs only. Some estimates are higher.[465] U.S. military costs | U.S. military aid to SVN | U.S. economic aid to SVN | Total | Total (2015 dollars)   
---|---|---|---|---  
$111 billion | $16.138 billion | $7.315 billion | $134.53 billion | $1.020 trillion   
  
In the post-war era, Americans struggled to absorb the lessons of the military
intervention.[466] As General [Maxwell Taylor](/wiki/Maxwell_D._Taylor
"Maxwell D. Taylor"), one of the principal architects of the war, noted,
"First, we didn't know ourselves. We thought that we were going into another
[Korean War](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War"), but this was a different country.
Secondly, we didn't know our South Vietnamese allies… And we knew less about
North Vietnam. Who was [Ho Chi Minh](/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh "Ho Chi Minh")? Nobody
really knew. So, until we know the enemy and know our allies and know
ourselves, we'd better keep out of this kind of dirty business. It's very
dangerous."[467][468] President [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald
Reagan") coined the term "[Vietnam Syndrome](/wiki/Vietnam_Syndrome "Vietnam
Syndrome")" to describe the reluctance of the American public and politicians
to support further international interventions after Vietnam. According to a
2004 Gallup poll, 62 percent of Americans believed it was an unjust war.[469]
US public polling in 1978 reveal nearly 72% of Americans believing the war was
"fundamentally wrong and immoral", nearly a decade later the number reduced to
66% and by 1985 to 2000 surveys consistently show 34–35% believing the war was
fundamentally wrong and immoral.[470] Nearly a third of Americans believed the
war was a noble cause when surveyed in 2000.[470]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Marine_da_nang.jpg/170px-
Marine_da_nang.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marine_da_nang.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marine_da_nang.jpg "Enlarge")

A young [Marine](/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps "United States Marine
Corps") private waits on the beach during the Marine landing, [Da
Nang](/wiki/Da_Nang "Da Nang"), 3 August 1965

Failure of the war is often placed at different institutions and levels. Some
have suggested that the failure of the war was due to political failures of
U.S. leadership.[471] The official history of the [United States
Army](/wiki/United_States_Army "United States Army") noted that
"[tactics](/wiki/Military_tactics "Military tactics") have often seemed to
exist apart from larger issues, strategies, and objectives. Yet in Vietnam the
Army experienced tactical success and strategic failure... success rests not
only on military progress but on correctly analysing the nature of the
particular conflict, understanding the enemy's strategy, and assessing the
strengths and weaknesses of allies. A new humility and a new sophistication
may form the best parts of a complex heritage left to the Army by the long,
bitter war in Vietnam."[181]

Others point to a failure of U.S. military doctrine. Secretary of Defense
Robert McNamara stated that "the achievement of a military victory by U.S.
forces in Vietnam was indeed a dangerous illusion."[472] The inability to
bring Hanoi to the bargaining table by bombing also illustrated another U.S.
miscalculation, and demonstrated the limitations of U.S. military abilities in
achieving political goals.[473] As [Army Chief of
Staff](/wiki/Chief_of_Staff_of_the_United_States_Army "Chief of Staff of the
United States Army") [Harold Keith Johnson](/wiki/Harold_Keith_Johnson "Harold
Keith Johnson") noted, "if anything came out of Vietnam, it was that air power
couldn't do the job."[474] Even General William Westmoreland admitted that the
bombing had been ineffective. As he remarked, "I still doubt that the North
Vietnamese would have relented."[474] U.S. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger
wrote in a secret memo to President Gerald Ford that "in terms of military
tactics, we cannot help draw the conclusion that our armed forces are not
suited to this kind of war. Even the Special Forces who had been designed for
it could not prevail."[475]

Hanoi had persistently sought unification of the country since the Geneva
Accords, and the effects of U.S. bombings had negligible diplomatic impacts on
the goals of the North Vietnamese government.[476] The effects of U.S. bombing
campaigns had mobilised the people throughout North Vietnam and mobilised
international support for North Vietnam due to the perception of a super-power
attempting to bomb a significantly smaller, agrarian society into
submission.[477]

The [Vietnam War POW/MIA issue](/wiki/Vietnam_War_POW/MIA_issue "Vietnam War
POW/MIA issue"), concerning the fate of U.S. service personnel listed as
[missing in action](/wiki/Missing_in_action "Missing in action"), persisted
for many years after the war's conclusion. The costs of the war loom large in
American popular consciousness; a 1990 poll showed that the public incorrectly
believed that more Americans lost their lives in Vietnam than in [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").[478]

#### Cost of the war

Between 1953 and 1975, the United States was estimated to have spent $168
billion on the war ($1.02 trillion in FY2015 dollars).[479] This resulted in a
large federal [budget deficit](/wiki/United_States_public_debt "United States
public debt"). Other figures point to $138.9 billion from 1965 to 1974 (not
inflation-adjusted), ten times the amount of support for all education
spending in the US and 50 times more than housing and community development
spending within that time period.[480] General record-keeping was reported to
have been sloppy for government spending during the war.[480] It was stated
that war-spending could have paid off every mortgage in the US at that time,
with money leftover.[480]

More than 3 million Americans served in the Vietnam War, some 1.5 million of
whom actually saw combat in Vietnam.[481] James E. Westheider wrote that "At
the height of American involvement in 1968, for example, there were 543,000
American military personnel in Vietnam, but only 80,000 were considered combat
troops."[482] [Conscription in the United
States](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the United
States") had been controlled by the president since World War II, but ended in
1973.

As of 2013, the U.S. government is paying Vietnam veterans and their families
or survivors more than $22 billion a year in war-related claims.[483][484]

#### Impact on the U.S. military

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/OperationHueCity1967wounded.jpg/220px-
OperationHueCity1967wounded.jpg)](/wiki/File:OperationHueCity1967wounded.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:OperationHueCity1967wounded.jpg "Enlarge")

Marine gets his wounds treated during operations in Huế City, 1968

By war's end, 58,220 American soldiers had been killed,[A 2] more than 150,000
had been wounded, and at least 21,000 had been permanently disabled.[485] The
average age of the U.S. troops killed in Vietnam was 23.11 years.[486]
According to Dale Kueter, "Of those killed in combat, 86.3 percent were white,
12.5 percent were black and the remainder from other races."[487]
Approximately 830,000 Vietnam veterans suffered some degree of [posttraumatic
stress disorder](/wiki/Posttraumatic_stress_disorder "Posttraumatic stress
disorder").[485] An estimated 125,000 Americans left for Canada to avoid the
Vietnam draft,[488] and approximately 50,000 American servicemen
deserted.[489] In 1977, United States president [Jimmy
Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter") granted a full and unconditional
pardon to all Vietnam-era [draft dodgers](/wiki/Draft_dodger "Draft
dodger").[490]

As the Vietnam War continued inconclusively and became more unpopular with the
American public, morale declined and disciplinary problems grew among American
enlisted men and junior, non-career officers. Drug use, racial tensions, and
the growing incidence of [fragging](/wiki/Fragging "Fragging")—attempting to
kill unpopular officers and non-commissioned officers with grenades or other
weapons—created severe problems for the U.S. military and impacted its
capability of undertaking combat operations. By 1971, a U.S. Army colonel
writing in the [Armed Forces Journal](/wiki/Armed_Forces_Journal "Armed Forces
Journal") declared: "By every conceivable indicator, our army that now remains
in Vietnam is in a state approaching collapse, with individual units avoiding
or having refused combat, murdering their officers and non commissioned
officers, drug-ridden, and dispirited where not near mutinous....The morale,
discipline, and battle-worthiness of the U.S. Armed Forces are, with a few
salient exceptions, lower and worse than at any time in this century and
possibly in the history of the United States."[491] Between 1969 and 1971 the
U.S. Army recorded more than 700 attacks by troops on their own officers.
Eighty-three officers were killed and almost 650 were injured.[492]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Robert_S._McNamara_and_General_Westmoreland_in_Vietnam_1965.png/220px-
Robert_S._McNamara_and_General_Westmoreland_in_Vietnam_1965.png)](/wiki/File:Robert_S._McNamara_and_General_Westmoreland_in_Vietnam_1965.png)

[](/wiki/File:Robert_S._McNamara_and_General_Westmoreland_in_Vietnam_1965.png
"Enlarge")

Secretary of Defense [Robert McNamara](/wiki/Robert_McNamara "Robert
McNamara") and [General Westmoreland](/wiki/William_Westmoreland "William
Westmoreland") talks with General Tee on condition of the war in Vietnam.

The Vietnam War called into question the U.S. Army doctrine. Marine Corps
General [Victor H. Krulak](/wiki/Victor_H._Krulak "Victor H. Krulak") heavily
criticised Westmoreland's [attrition](/wiki/Attrition_warfare "Attrition
warfare") strategy, calling it "wasteful of American lives… with small
likelihood of a successful outcome."[474] In addition, doubts surfaced about
the ability of the military to train foreign forces. Furthermore, throughout
the war there was found to be considerable flaws and dishonesty by officers
and commanders due to promotions being tied to the [body count
system](/wiki/Body_count#Vietnam_War "Body count") touted by Westmoreland and
McNamara.[493]

Ron Milam has questioned the severity of the "breakdown" of the U.S. armed
forces, especially among combat troops, as reflecting the opinions of "angry
colonels" who deplored the erosion of traditional military values during the
Vietnam War.[494] Although acknowledging serious problems, he questions the
alleged "near mutinous" conduct of junior officers and enlisted men in combat.
Investigating one combat refusal incident, a journalist declared, "A certain
sense of independence, a reluctance to behave according to the military's
insistence on obedience, like pawns or puppets...The grunts [infantrymen] were
determined to survive...they insisted of having something to say about the
making of decisions that determined whether they might live or die."[495] The
morale and discipline problems and resistance to
[conscription](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the
United States") (the draft) were important factors leading to the creation of
an all-volunteer military force by the United States and the termination of
conscription. The last conscript was inducted into the army in 1973.[496][497]
The all-volunteer military moderated some of the coercive methods of
discipline previously used to maintain order in military ranks.[498]

### Effects of U.S. chemical defoliation

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Defoliation_agent_spraying.jpg/220px-
Defoliation_agent_spraying.jpg)](/wiki/File:Defoliation_agent_spraying.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Defoliation_agent_spraying.jpg "Enlarge")

U.S. helicopter spraying chemical [defoliants](/wiki/Defoliant "Defoliant") in
the [Mekong Delta](/wiki/Mekong_Delta "Mekong Delta"), South Vietnam, 1969

One of the most controversial aspects of the U.S. military effort in Southeast
Asia was the widespread use of chemical [defoliants](/wiki/Defoliant
"Defoliant") between 1961 and 1971. They were used to
[defoliate](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/defoliate "wikt:defoliate") large
parts of the countryside to prevent the Viet Cong from being able to hide
their weapons and encampments under the foliage. These chemicals continue to
change the landscape, cause diseases and birth defects, and poison the food
chain.[499][500]

Early in the American military effort, it was decided that since the enemy
were hiding their activities under triple-canopy jungle, a useful first step
might be to defoliate certain areas. This was especially true of growth
surrounding bases (both large and small) in what became known as [Operation
Ranch Hand](/wiki/Operation_Ranch_Hand "Operation Ranch Hand"). Corporations
like [Dow Chemical Company](/wiki/Dow_Chemical_Company "Dow Chemical Company")
and [Monsanto](/wiki/Monsanto "Monsanto") were given the task of developing
herbicides for this purpose. American officials also pointed out that the
British had previously used [2,4,5-T](/wiki/2,4,5-T "2,4,5-T") and
[2,4-D](/wiki/2,4-D "2,4-D") (virtually identical to America's use in Vietnam)
on a large scale throughout the [Malayan Emergency](/wiki/Malayan_Emergency
"Malayan Emergency") in the 1950s in order to destroy bushes, crops, and trees
in effort to deny communist insurgents the concealment they needed to ambush
passing convoys.[501] Indeed, Secretary of State [Dean Rusk](/wiki/Dean_Rusk
"Dean Rusk") told President [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F.
Kennedy") on 24 November 1961, that "[t]he use of defoliant does not violate
any rule of [international law](/wiki/International_law "International law")
concerning the conduct of chemical warfare and is an accepted tactic of war.
Precedent has been established by the British during the emergency in Malaya
in their use of aircraft for destroying crops by chemical spraying."[502]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/A_vietnamese_Professor_is_pictured_with_a_group_of_handicapped_children.jpg/220px-
A_vietnamese_Professor_is_pictured_with_a_group_of_handicapped_children.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_vietnamese_Professor_is_pictured_with_a_group_of_handicapped_children.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_vietnamese_Professor_is_pictured_with_a_group_of_handicapped_children.jpg
"Enlarge")

Handicapped children in Vietnam, most of them victims of [Agent
Orange](/wiki/Agent_Orange "Agent Orange"), 2004

The defoliants, which were distributed in drums marked with color-coded bands,
included the "[Rainbow Herbicides](/wiki/Rainbow_Herbicides "Rainbow
Herbicides")"—[Agent Pink](/wiki/Agent_Pink "Agent Pink"), [Agent
Green](/wiki/Agent_Green "Agent Green"), [Agent Purple](/wiki/Agent_Purple
"Agent Purple"), [Agent Blue](/wiki/Agent_Blue "Agent Blue"), [Agent
White](/wiki/Agent_White "Agent White"), and most famously, [Agent
Orange](/wiki/Agent_Orange "Agent Orange"), which included
[dioxin](/wiki/Polychlorinated_dibenzodioxins "Polychlorinated
dibenzodioxins") as a byproduct of its manufacture. About 11–12 million
gallons (41.6–45.4 million L) of Agent Orange were sprayed over southern
Vietnam between 1961 and 1971.[503] A prime area of Ranch Hand operations was
in the [Mekong Delta](/wiki/Mekong_Delta "Mekong Delta"), where the U.S. Navy
patrol boats were vulnerable to attack from the undergrowth at the water's
edge.

In 1961 and 1962, the Kennedy administration authorized the use of chemicals
to destroy rice crops. Between 1961 and 1967, the U.S. Air Force sprayed 20
million U.S. gallons (75,700,000 L) of concentrated herbicides over 6 million
acres (24,000 km2) of crops and trees, affecting an estimated 13% of South
Vietnam's land. In 1965, 42% of all herbicide was sprayed over food crops.
Another purpose of herbicide use was to drive civilian populations into RVN-
controlled areas.[504]

Vietnamese victims affected by Agent Orange attempted a class action lawsuit
against Dow Chemical and other U.S. chemical manufacturers, but [District
Court](/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Eastern_District_of_New_York
"United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York") Judge
[Jack B. Weinstein](/wiki/Jack_B._Weinstein "Jack B. Weinstein") dismissed
their case.[505] They appealed, but the dismissal was cemented in February
2008 by the [Court of Appeals for the Second
Circuit](/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Second_Circuit "United
States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit").[506] As of
2006[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Vietnam_War&action=edit),
the Vietnamese government estimates that there are over 4,000,000 victims of
[dioxin](/wiki/Dioxin "Dioxin") poisoning in Vietnam, although the United
States government denies any conclusive scientific links between Agent Orange
and the Vietnamese victims of dioxin poisoning. In some areas of southern
Vietnam, dioxin levels remain at over 100 times the accepted international
standard.[507]

In 2006, Anh Duc Ngo and colleagues of the [University of Texas Health Science
Center](/wiki/University_of_Texas_Health_Science_Center "University of Texas
Health Science Center") published a [meta-analysis](/wiki/Meta-analysis "Meta-
analysis") that exposed a large amount of heterogeneity (different findings)
between studies, a finding consistent with a lack of consensus on the issue on
the effect of Agent Orange in Vietnam.[508] Despite this, statistical analysis
of the studies they examined resulted in data that the increase in birth
defects/[relative risk](/wiki/Relative_risk "Relative risk") (RR) from
exposure to agent orange/dioxin "appears" to be on the order of 3 in
Vietnamese-funded studies, but 1.29 in the rest of the world. There is data
near the threshold of [statistical
significance](/wiki/Statistical_significance "Statistical significance")
suggesting Agent Orange contributes to still-births, cleft palate, and [neural
tube defects](/wiki/Neural_tube_defects "Neural tube defects"), with [spina
bifida](/wiki/Spina_bifida "Spina bifida") being the most statistically
significant defect.[509] The large discrepancy in RR between Vietnamese
studies and those in the rest of the world has been ascribed to bias in the
Vietnamese studies.[508]

The U.S. Veterans Administration has listed [prostate
cancer](/wiki/Prostate_cancer "Prostate cancer"), [respiratory
cancers](/wiki/Lung_cancer "Lung cancer"), [multiple
myeloma](/wiki/Multiple_myeloma "Multiple myeloma"), [Diabetes mellitus type
2](/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus_type_2 "Diabetes mellitus type 2"), [B-cell
lymphomas](/wiki/B-cell_lymphomas "B-cell lymphomas"), [soft-tissue
sarcoma](/wiki/Soft-tissue_sarcoma "Soft-tissue sarcoma"),
[chloracne](/wiki/Chloracne "Chloracne"), [porphyria cutanea
tarda](/wiki/Porphyria_cutanea_tarda "Porphyria cutanea tarda"), [peripheral
neuropathy](/wiki/Peripheral_neuropathy "Peripheral neuropathy"), and [spina
bifida](/wiki/Spina_bifida "Spina bifida") in children of veterans exposed to
Agent Orange.[510]

Estimates of the number of casualties vary, with one source suggesting up to
3.8 million violent war deaths in Vietnam for the period 1955 to 2002.[513] A
detailed demographic study calculated 791,000–1,141,000 war-related deaths
during the war for all of Vietnam, for both military and civilians.[43]
Between 195,000 and 430,000 South Vietnamese civilians died in the
war.[44][53] Extrapolating from a 1969 US intelligence report, Guenter Lewy
estimated 65,000 North Vietnamese civilians died in the war.[44] Estimates of
civilian deaths caused by American bombing of North Vietnam in [Operation
Rolling Thunder](/wiki/Operation_Rolling_Thunder "Operation Rolling Thunder")
range from 30,000[514][515] to 182,000.[516] A 1974 [US
Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") subcommittee
estimates nearly 1.4 million civilians killed and wounded between 1965 and
1974, and attributed over half as resulting from US and South Vietnamese
military action.[227]

The military forces of South Vietnam suffered an estimated 254,256 killed
between 1960 and 1974 and additional deaths from 1954 to 1959 and in
1975.[517] Other estimates point to higher figures of 313,000 casualties.[120]
The official US Department of Defense figure was 950,765 PAVN/NLF forces
killed in Vietnam from 1965 to 1974. Defense Department officials believed
that these body count figures need to be deflated by 30 percent. In addition,
Guenter Lewy assumes that one-third of the [reported "enemy"
killed](/wiki/Body_count#Vietnam_War "Body count") may have been civilians,
concluding that the actual number of deaths of PAVN/PLAF military forces was
probably closer to 444,000.[44]

According to figures from internal
PAVN/[PLAF](/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Armed_Forces_of_South_Vietnam
"People's Liberation Armed Forces of South Vietnam") figures released by the
Vietnamese government there was 849,018 military deaths on the PAVN/NLF side
during the war.[46][518][519][520] The Vietnamese government released its
estimate of war deaths for the more lengthy period of 1955 to 1975. This
figure includes battle deaths of Vietnamese soldiers in [Laotian Civil
War](/wiki/Laotian_Civil_War "Laotian Civil War") and [Cambodian Civil
War](/wiki/Cambodian_Civil_War "Cambodian Civil War") in which the PAVN was a
major participant and 30–40% of the figure are non-combat deaths,[46] but does
not include deaths of South Vietnamese and allied soldiers.[521]

US reports of "enemy KIA", referred to as [body
count](/wiki/Body_count#Vietnam_War "Body count") were thought to have been
subject to "falsification and glorification", and a true estimate of PAVN/NLF
combat deaths may be difficult to assess, as US victories were assessed by
having a "greater kill ratio".[522][523][524] It was difficult to distinguish
between civilians and military personnel on the Viet Cong side as many persons
were part-time guerrillas or impressed labourers who did not wear
uniforms[525][526][527] and civilians actually killed were oftentimes written
off as enemy KIA.[528][529] MACV operation rarely made a distinction between
unarmed civilians and combatants, there was drastic inflation of enemy
casualties since it was directly tied to promotions and commendation.[530]

Between 275,000[74] and 310,000[75] Cambodians were estimated to have died
during the war including between 40,000 and 150,000 combatants and civilians
from US bombings.[75][531][532] 20,000–62,000 Laotians also died,[72] and
58,318 U.S. military personnel were killed,[57] of which 1,598 are still
listed as missing as of 2018.[533]

[Unexploded ordnance](/wiki/Unexploded_ordnance "Unexploded ordnance"), mostly
from U.S. bombing, continue to detonate and kill people today. According to
the Vietnamese government, ordnance has killed some 42,000 people since the
war officially ended.[534][535] According to the government of Laos,
unexploded ordnance has killed or injured over 20,000 Laotians since the end
of the war.[455] Casualties from Agent Orange exposure is not known currently.

### In popular culture

The Vietnam War has been featured extensively in television, film, video
games, music and literature in the participant countries. In Vietnam, one
notable film set during Operation Linebacker II was the film _[Girl from
Hanoi](/wiki/Girl_from_Hanoi "Girl from Hanoi")_ (1975) depicting war-time
life in Hanoi. Another notable work was the diary of [Đặng Thùy
Trâm](/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%B7ng_Th%C3%B9y_Tr%C3%A2m "Đặng Thùy Trâm"), a
Vietnamese doctor who enlisted in the Southern battlefield, and was killed at
the age of 27 by US forces near [Quảng Ngãi](/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Ng%C3%A3i
"Quảng Ngãi"). Her diaries were later published in Vietnam as _Đặng Thùy Trâm
's Diary_ (_Last Night I Dreamed Of Peace_), where it became a best-seller and
was later made into a film _[Don't Burn](/wiki/Don%27t_Burn "Don't Burn")_
(_Đừng Đốt_). In Vietnam the diary has often been compared to _[The Diary of
Anne Frank](/wiki/The_Diary_of_a_Young_Girl "The Diary of a Young Girl")_ and
both are used in literary education.[536] Another Vietnamese film produced was
_[The Abandoned Field: Free Fire
Zone](/wiki/The_Abandoned_Field:_Free_Fire_Zone "The Abandoned Field: Free
Fire Zone")_ (_Cánh đồng hoang)_ in 1979 which weaves the narrative of living
on the ground in a US "free-fire zone" as well as perspectives from US
helicopters.

In American popular culture, the "Crazy Vietnam Veteran", who was suffering
from [posttraumatic stress disorder](/wiki/Posttraumatic_stress_disorder
"Posttraumatic stress disorder"), became a common [stock
character](/wiki/Stock_character "Stock character") after the war.

One of the first major films based on the Vietnam War was [John
Wayne](/wiki/John_Wayne "John Wayne")'s pro-war film, _[The Green
Berets](/wiki/The_Green_Berets_\(film\) "The Green Berets \(film\)")_ (1968).
Further cinematic representations were released during the 1970s and 1980s,
including [Michael Cimino](/wiki/Michael_Cimino "Michael Cimino")'s _[The Deer
Hunter](/wiki/The_Deer_Hunter "The Deer Hunter")_ (1978), [Francis Ford
Coppola](/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola "Francis Ford Coppola")'s _[Apocalypse
Now](/wiki/Apocalypse_Now "Apocalypse Now")_ (1979), [Oliver
Stone](/wiki/Oliver_Stone "Oliver Stone")'s _[Platoon](/wiki/Platoon_\(film\)
"Platoon \(film\)")_ (1986) – based on his service in the [U.S.
military](/wiki/U.S._military "U.S. military") during the Vietnam War,
[Stanley Kubrick](/wiki/Stanley_Kubrick "Stanley Kubrick")'s _[Full Metal
Jacket](/wiki/Full_Metal_Jacket "Full Metal Jacket")_ (1987), _[Hamburger
Hill](/wiki/Hamburger_Hill "Hamburger Hill")_ (1987), _[Born on the Fourth of
July](/wiki/Born_on_the_Fourth_of_July_\(film\) "Born on the Fourth of July
\(film\)")_ (1989), and _[Casualties of War](/wiki/Casualties_of_War
"Casualties of War")_ (1989). Later films would include _[We Were
Soldiers](/wiki/We_Were_Soldiers "We Were Soldiers")_ (2002) and _[Rescue
Dawn](/wiki/Rescue_Dawn "Rescue Dawn")_ (2007).[56]

The war also influenced a generation of musicians and songwriters in Vietnam
and the United States, both anti-war and pro/anti-communist. The band [Country
Joe and the Fish](/wiki/Country_Joe_and_the_Fish "Country Joe and the Fish")
recorded ["I-Feel-Like-I'm-Fixin'-To-Die Rag" / The "Fish"
Cheer](/wiki/The_%22Fish%22_Cheer/I-Feel-Like-I%27m-Fixin%27-To-Die_Rag "The
"Fish" Cheer/I-Feel-Like-I'm-Fixin'-To-Die Rag") in 1965, and it became one of
the most influential anti-Vietnam protest anthems.[56] Many songwriters and
musicians supported the anti-war movement, including [Pete
Seeger](/wiki/Pete_Seeger "Pete Seeger"), [Joan Baez](/wiki/Joan_Baez "Joan
Baez"), [Peggy Seeger](/wiki/Peggy_Seeger "Peggy Seeger"), [Ewan
MacColl](/wiki/Ewan_MacColl "Ewan MacColl"), [Barbara Dane](/wiki/Barbara_Dane
"Barbara Dane"), [The Critics Group](/wiki/The_Critics_Group "The Critics
Group"), [Phil Ochs](/wiki/Phil_Ochs "Phil Ochs"), [John
Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon"), [Nina Simone](/wiki/Nina_Simone
"Nina Simone"), [Neil Young](/wiki/Neil_Young "Neil Young"), [Tom
Paxton](/wiki/Tom_Paxton "Tom Paxton"), [Jimmy Cliff](/wiki/Jimmy_Cliff "Jimmy
Cliff") and [Arlo Guthrie](/wiki/Arlo_Guthrie "Arlo Guthrie").

#### Myths

Myths play a central role in the [historiography](/wiki/Historiography
"Historiography") of the Vietnam War, and have become a part of the [culture
of the United States](/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States "Culture of the
United States"). Much like the general historiography of the war, discussion
of myth has focused on US experiences; but, changing myths of war have also
played a role in [Vietnamese](/wiki/Vietnam "Vietnam") and
[Australian](/wiki/Australia "Australia") historiography.

Recent scholarship has focused on "myth-busting",[537] attacking the previous
orthodox and revisionist schools of American historiography of the Vietnam
War. This scholarship challenges myths about American society and soldiery in
the Vietnam War.[538]

Kuzmarov in _The Myth of the Addicted Army: Vietnam and the Modern War on
Drugs_ challenges the popular and Hollywood narrative that US soldiers were
heavy drug users, and in particular destroys the concept that the [My Lai
massacre](/wiki/My_Lai_massacre "My Lai massacre") was caused by drug
use.[539] According to Kuzmarov, [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard
Nixon") is primarily responsible for creating the drug myth.[540]

Michael Allen in _Until The Last Man Comes Home_ also accuses Nixon of myth
making, by exploiting the plight of the [League of Wives of American Prisoners
in
Vietnam](/w/index.php?title=League_of_Wives_of_American_Prisoners_in_Vietnam&action=edit&redlink=1
"League of Wives of American Prisoners in Vietnam \(page does not exist\)")
and the [National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in
Southeast
Asia](/wiki/National_League_of_Families_of_American_Prisoners_and_Missing_in_Southeast_Asia
"National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast
Asia") to allow the government to appear caring as the war was increasingly
considered lost.[541] Allen's analysis ties the position of potential missing
or prisoner Americans into post-war politics and recent presidential
elections, including the [Swift boat](/wiki/Swift_Vets_and_POWs_for_Truth
"Swift Vets and POWs for Truth") controversy in US electoral politics.[542]

### Commemoration

On May 25, 2012, President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama")
issued a [proclamation](/wiki/Presidential_proclamation "Presidential
proclamation") of the [commemoration of the 50th Anniversary of the Vietnam
War](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Proclamation_8829 "s:Proclamation
8829").[543][544] On November 10, 2017, President [Donald
Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") issued an additional [proclamation
commemorating the 50th Anniversary of the Vietnam
War](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Proclamation_9674 "s:Proclamation
9674").[545][546][547][548]
